elements.text: [Part One]

Dark Space Eight, status report. Day 4,814 of operation. Chief Medic Eleanor Harcourt reporting. We are gradually beginning to overcome our grief at the loss of Commander Keel. The subdued mood in the corridors of the station among the 210 men and women of the crew is beginning to lift. Our new mission orders have been received, and we await the arrival of our new commander in an atmosphere of cool serenity and undisturbed tranquillity.
Alarms sound.

Oh, I’m so sorry. I accidentally hit the Red Alert switch there. (alarm stops) Sorry, everyone. Our new commander will take the helm of Dark Space Eight on a crucial mission at a crucial moment in the history of the whole galaxy. End of status report.
Well done, Eleanor. The Commander’s death has hit us all for six, but I know how close you were.
I can’t help feeling responsible, Ivor.
Oh, there’s not much that anybody, even a top medic like you, can do about the Orion flu.
True. But I could have stopped him going off to confront that silicon-based entity in the first place.

Come on, Paul Keel knew the risks better than anyone. He destroyed that creature and its scheme to enslave all carbon-based life, saved the whole crew. He wasn’t to know that in the process the being would infect him with an incurable plague, totally resistant to all treatment.
I know. I just felt so helpless.
Well, his replacement’s due any moment. We ought to get to the shuttle dock, roll out the red carpet, hmm? Eleanor?
I was just thinking.
Oh, penny for them?
A crucial mission, that’s what I said on the log.
Well

It’s hardly that. Dark Space Eight has seen better days. Seven years we’ve been out here, Ivor, on the furthest edge of known space. Seven years of adventure and intrigue. The newer stations are better equipped with fresh new crews. This mission sums it all up. Achilles Four gets the All-Worlds Peace Convention. Star Island Twelve gets the Embassy to the Shadrock Empire. What do we get? The Intergalactic Song Contest.
Well, look on the bright side. Should be a fairly uneventful few days.
Alarms sound briefly. Angry voices.
Sorry, sorry.
We really must move that switch.
Various languages, then

Please acknowledge. Align beacon to shuttleport D. Thank you, Zellerite escort. You are clear to dock. Dark Space Eight traffic control to Breeble escort. You are now clear to dock at port F. Please proceed. Dark Space Eight traffic control to Earth Gholos escort shuttle. Please acknowledge (fades out)
Imagine your host for the show is the late Sir Terry Wogan...

(Irish) Hello. It’s the 309" Intergalactic Song Contest. (sigh) This is Logan, and here I am again, here we are again. I’m with my producer, Martin. I can see him waving up at me from the reception hall, trying frantically to escape, ha, ha. The entrants are just docking here at Dark Space Eight, and the excitement’s bearable. Sorry, I mean, unbearable. Or do I? 309 years, eh, and it doesn’t seem a day too long. Ah, here comes the first contestant, from Angvia. It’s a real pity I’m doing this broadcast on sound only, because if you could see her you’d all have a laugh. It’s Ride of the Valkyries all over again. If I can just describe. You know the Angvians are a matriarchal society? This lady certainly frightens me. Makes Mrs Logan look only a wee dragon in comparison. She’s a big lass, and it looks like someone’s tipped a jeweller’s window out on her head. Now the Angvian entry is Gor-raz A Det, which I’m told translates roughly as my love is limitless, like a black hole, and I’m pulling you over the event horizon. A sentiment we can all share, there. Of course, the planet Angvia has been locked in war with Gholos now for quite some time.
Cheers.

Oh dear, I hope she hurries along there. I can see the Gholos entry coming along. Ah yes, Gholos. Gholos, of course, is a vast gestalt entity. A sort of big, wispy, cloudy, transcendental thing. From where I’m sitting he looks just like a big ball of candyfloss. Of course, this is only one small part of Gholos. The singing

part, I imagine. His entry is, well, I’m not even going to try and pronounce that one. It’s very difficult to understand the Gholos language. In fact, I see he’s brought an interpreter along with him. Rather him than me.
Cheers.

Ah. Ah ha! Bet you can’t guess who that is. It’s our own Earth entry, young Nicky Newman, fresh- faced as ever. His mam obviously gave him a good scrub-over before she let him out today. (laughs) No shortage of volunteers for that job, of course. Those lusty screams you can hear are coming from Earth, via the vidi-globe hovering behind the lad. Maybe you should get one of those for yourself, Logan. Ah. Ah well, maybe not. Behind him I can just see the Cyrene entrant. A funny lot, those Cyrenes. A bit too much like Medusa for my liking. You wouldn’t want to wake up next to one after a heavy night, I can tell you. Anyway, the Cyrene entry, and a popular choice with the space bookies, this one (continues faintly under -)
Dark Space Eight to Command shuttle. Come in, please. Respond, please.
Door opens.
You’ve never actually worked with the new Commander?
Door closes.
Er, no, no, just know him by repute. And it is quite a repute. He was the head of the Perseus expedition, you know.

The Perseus expedition. Didn’t they come into contact with a computer left behind by an ancient civilisation that tried to enslave their minds and made them believe they were living in some kind of Nirvana?
That’s the one, yes. John Ballard’s quick thinking saved the day. His mind was just too strong for the computer to control.
Doctor Harcourt, Professor Fassbinder?
Yes, Lieutenant?
The shuttle carrying the new commander. I’m having trouble making contact.
It’s a very busy docking schedule. Possibly our communicators can’t cope with the strain of all the traffic. Electromagnetic radiation overload.
No, Professor. All the systems are functioning perfectly. I’ve performed all the usual checks. There’s just no answer.
Well then, I just don’t know.
What if we carried out a data sweep, using our forward sensor array?
Good idea, Eleanor. Er, Lieutenant Strindberg, see to it. And switch off that drivel while you’re at it.
Right away, Professor.
Perhaps the shuttle’s communicator has failed?
A ship like that’s top of the fleet. There’s be back-up systems galore. No, it’s very odd.
Professor, Doctor.
What is it, Lieutenant?
These readings don’t make sense. The data sweep indicates a build-up of some form of energy on board the command shuttle.
What sort of energy?
It’s some form of fluctuating chronon surge. I’ve never seen anything like it before.
We've got to get in touch with that shuttle.
Command shuttle, come in. It’s imperative that you respond.
[OC]: Command shuttle, this is Dark Space Eight. Respond please. Come in, Command shuttle. There’s a build-up of energy aboard your vessel. Command shuttle, this is Dark Space Eight.
continues under -
The Tardis materialises. Tardis door opens.

Here we are, Mel. La Maison Rouge. The finest restaurant in Paris. The air is like wine, the wine is like nectar, and I booked table cing overlooking the twilight Seine as it snakes down to the Bois du Boulogne. Oh.
Oh, Doctor, not again.
Tardis door closes.
Um. Perhaps there’s been a power cut. Henri! Henri! C’est le Docteur!
Stop trying to wriggle out of it. This isn’t Paris, and you know it.
Mmn,, I'll admit the corrugated iron isn’t quite in keeping with the usual Parisian ambience.
Lost again.
Well, if you want to know the way, ask a gendarme. Come along. There’s a light up ahead.
Air like wine, you said.
No, more like a mercurial compound mixed with something nitric and nasty.
[OC]: Respond Command shuttle.
Command shuttle? This is a spaceship. We’re nowhere near Paris.
Unless it’s heading for France.
Oh, give it up, Doctor. I oh! Oh no.
Two of them. Poor fellows.
Doctor, they’re dead. What was it you said? Something nitric?
Yes. They were gassed. The vapour’s dispersed, luckily for us.
[OC]: It’s no good, sir.
Let’s respond, let them know what’s happened.
Wait. What’s that noise?
I can’t hear anything.
Shh.
Ticking.
It’s coming from the controls, down there.
There’s something attached. Oh dear.
It’s not a bomb. It’s a bomb!
Run, Mel! The Tardis.
Boom!
Alarms.
Confirmed. The shuttle has exploded. Total destruction.
Will somebody kill that alarm? Please? Thank you.
I hope we got them out in time.
The matter-beam pad. Something’s coming through.
Quickly. What?
Huh?
Thank goodness.
We must have locked onto their lifesigns just in time.
Commander?
Er, parlez-vous frangais?
(sotto) Give it up, Doctor.
He must be disorientated.
Lieutenant Strindberg, fetch some water.
: Sir.
Commander Ballard, Chief Medical Officer Eleanor Harcourt reporting. What happened out there, sir? Was there a malfunction on the shuttle?
Ah, er, yes, er, no, well, I’m not certain. I mean, it all happened so quickly.
We detected an energy flare. Pilot, didn’t you hear us trying to contact you? Pilot.
Me? Ah, er, ah, er, no. No, we didn’t hear a thing.
Here, drink these.
Thank you. Oh, that’s better.
Yes, what did I tell you. It must have been an overload of magnetic radiation.
Enough to destroy the shuttle?
I just don’t Know, Eleanor. Radiation of that kind is pretty unpredictable.
I think we should let the Commander and er
Mel. Er, Pilot Melanie Bush.
The Commander and Pilot Bush rest, Ivor. I'll show you to your living quarters.
Oh, thank you, Doctor. Lead on. Well done, Mel. You really are very good at that sort of thing.
Travelling with you I have to be. What's the plan, then? Use our new aliases to get back to the Tardis? It must be floating about out there in space.
Ah yes, a very good idea.
You mean, that wasn’t your plan?
Oh, I didn’t have a plan. I was just making it up as I went along.
Fizzing sound.
Yes, yes, I am as concerned as you are. I quite agree, Gholos. There must be an investigation. Security here is a joke. I will draft a strongly worded letter to ah. What have we here?
And round this corner here is where we were invaded by the Arcons of Aristarcus.
Really? How interesting.
Ah, excuse me. Are you in what passes for a position of authority on this hulk?
I am the station’s Chief Medical Officer, Doctor Eleanor
What has happened to the Commander’s shuttle? We saw it blow up.
This is the Commander.
You?
Yes. Appearances aren’t everything.
We were teleported off the shuttle just in time.
It was simply a technical fault. Our people are looking into it. Luckily, Commander Ballard was rescued. Forgive me, you are?
Don’t you recognise the entity Gholos?
Ah. The entity Gholos. Of course. How do you do? How is life in the gestalt these days? Oh, how fascinating.
You speak Gholosian?
Ah, no, of course not. Rather a complicated tongue even for as keen a student of linguistics as myself.

It took me fifteen years of advanced study to grasp the bare rudiments. And you’re wrong, Commander. Gholosian isn’t a tongue of any kind. Rather a complex series of signals framed in semiotic strings.
A short Gholosian fizz required a lot of words, a long one, not very many.
I get it. You’re the interpreter.
A system of communication eminently richer and more complex than any humanoid language.
Excuse me, Mister?
Loozly.
Mister Loozly, but I have to take the Commander and his Pilot to their quarters. They've been through a very stressful experience out there in space.
Gholos too finds the current situation stressful, but I
A high-pitched voice very like Alpha Centauri.
I must speak to somebody in authority at once.
Oh, no. Er, Commander, I think you’d better take charge of the situation.
What has happened to the shuttle? Could this be an alien attack, or sabotage?
Well, Cyrenean, Gholos was just trying to ascertain the very same thing.
Our lives are in danger.
We must know the truth.
Yes, we have a right to be told.
Gholos is anxious that the proper authorities be informed at once if there is even the slightest threat to our persons.
I am in accord.
As I have explained, there is absolutely (fades under)
Doctor.
Pass me your whistle.
What whistle?
The one in your jacket pocket.
Eh? How did that get there?
The Doctor blows a referee’s whistle.
Thank you. Now, given the er, delicate nature of the current affairs, you are rightly concerned. But we all have to pull together for the good of the er, the conference, er, convention, er
The Intergalactic Song Contest.
The what? I mean, of course. The Intergalactic Song Contest.
Absolutely. A full investigation will be carried out into the explosion, gentlemen.
Gentlemen?

Gentlepersons. Er, gentlebeings. So, please go back to your quarters and prepare for the er Song Contest. All this shouting is bad for your vocal chords, or whatever it is you'll be using to sing with.
Commander, what you may not realise, and what Gholos has confirmed to me, is that the explosion of your shuttle displayed the unmistakable blast pattern of an Angvian scatter-bomb.
No! Surely even the Angvians would not be so bold. We are merely entertainers. I only came here to raise my galactic profile. I have no interest in politics.
Neither has Gholos. He has entertained the gestalt with his song-stories for seven cycles. (talks under -)
Oh, Mister Loozly, please, you’ve caused nothing but disruption since you came here.
Whistle blown.
Quiet, all of you.
Enter Magenta, or Belazs if you prefer.
Well spoken, girl. You are commander?
What? Yes.
This child has shown more strength than you dealing with these squabbling fools.
Queen Angvia, I presume.
Ha. And this woman, she shows more brain than you, little man.
Protect us, Commander. An Angvian warship is probably already on the way.
Pah! I see Angvia is to be blamed for everything as usual. We did not destroy the craft.
Gholos will not accept the word of any Angvian. Your primitive race has shown its treacherous
nature on many occasions.
Ha, ha, ha! It was not the people of Angvia who broke the Peace Treaty of Tenebros Four.
And it was not Gholos who settled the fringe planets of the Zordon Nebula, in direct contradiction of the Treaty’s terms.
Our battle cruisers were invited in by the peoples of Zordon.
Please, this is getting us nowhere.
Quite. As I said, return to your quarters.
And wait for the Angvian attack?

Good creatures, why would our mighty armies concern themselves with this contest? I am here for the same reason as all of you. To sing. My monologues are famous the wide galaxy over. The only politics I care for are the politics of this contest. Commander, the running order of the songs is a clear attempt by Earth to marginalise us.
The running order was decided fairly, by lot.
And we of Angvia are almost last.
Yes, you'll never get a chance to sing one of your precious monologues before your heavy cruisers blast this station into so much space debris.
I’m sure we can sort this matter out amicably.
I have never appeared so low down on a bill, even when I supported the Frezznix of Rass.
Gholos has a suggestion. Why don't the planets appear in alphabetical order?
An excellent idea. Very diplomatic. Thank you, Gholos.
Gholos is sure the viewing billions will be glad Angvia is over and done with so near the start.
Ah, how dare you!
Good. Now, all settled? Come along, Mel. Doctor Handcraft?
It’s Harcourt, Commander.
(receding) Oh yes. Oh, I’m so sorry. Yes, let’s get to our quarters, eh?
Well, as far as I’m concerned, the Angvia situation is something of a waste of time. We do not need any (arguments fade)
Your lifesigns seem to be normal. I suggest you rest for a couple of hours. The contest doesn’t begin until 2000 hours station time.
Thank you, Doctor Har
Harcourt.
Court.
I’m sorry your welcome didn’t go quite as planned, Commander, but with the Peace Conference in session on Achilles Four, everyone is rather on edge. War is uppermost in the minds of us all.
Yes, of course. Quite understand. Achilles Four, yes. That conference between er
Between Gholos and Angvia, Commander. You’re quite sure that there isn’t any lingering disorientation?
Er, no, no, no. Fit as a tree. Thank you again, Doctor.
A pleasure, Commander. Now I must return to my duties.
Door opens and closes.
All right. Are you going to explain all that brouhaha out in the corridor?
The what?
The brouhaha. The argument.
Well, it’s all rather interesting, actually. Angvia and Gholos are neighbouring empires.
And deadly enemies. That much was obvious.
For many centuries they’ve been at each other’s opposable organs. Don’t you know your history, Mel?
We only got as far as Tudors and Stuarts, Doctor.
The Tudors. Splendid chaps, all of them.
Hmm. Back to the point.
Centuries of bitter territorial conflict, border intrusions, neighbours from hell indeed.
A dislike for the unlike?

Not really. They're both pretty horrible. This contest is fascinating, Mel. A pivotal moment in universal history. Must be the first time Gholos and Angvia have been in the same corridor without trying to evaporate each other.
Never mind all that now. We’ve got to get the Tardis back.
The Tardis? Oh yes. Oh well, there’s no need to hurry. Fools rush in where horses fear to drink.
You're getting interested and involved, aren’t you?
Does it show? Come on, Mel, don’t deny you love a good sing-song.
And you love a good mystery.
Then we'll both be as happy as sandcastles.
You’re the Commander, right? Why not contact that scientist and get him to scan the debris from the
shuttle. Then he can use a tractor beam to bring in the Tardis.
Oh, yes. One of those. Good idea. Ah, this must be my communicator. (beep) Hello. Is that the Science Officer?
[OC]: Yes, Commander. Fassbinder here.
Hello. I’d like you to scan the debris from the shuttle. Use the tractor beam to bring in anything of interest for analysis.
[OC]: Right away, Commander. (beep)
Do you know, I’ve always wanted one of these. Commander’s perks. Ah, this must be my uniform. Very heroic.
Before you get totally carried away, aren’t you forgetting something?
I don’t know. You'll have to remind me. Oh, this jacket fits like a glove.
Doctor, we found a bomb on that shuttle. Somebody was trying to kill the Commander, and by taking his identity you’ve painted us into a very dangerous corner.
Yes, perhaps you're right, Mel. We must tread carefully. Softly, softly catches the worm, eh, Mel?
Would you please stop doing that proverb thing, Doctor? It’s really annoying.
Oh. Sorry.

Dark Space Eight status report, day 4,815 of operation. Chief Medic Eleanor Harcourt reporting. We are continuing to investigate the mysterious explosion of the Commander’s shuttle as the contest draws near. Commander Ballard is an intriguing man, with a natural air of authority and dignity, and I hope our relationship will be as interesting, rewarding and close as that between myself and Commander Keel. Harcourt out.
Welcome back. Ha, ha, ha. It’s busy, busy, busy here in the great Concert Hall, formerly the Quarantine Area, ha, ha. Well, not really. That noise you can hear is the Cyrene backing band tuning up.
Gurgles doing tuneful scales.

Nothing to do with Mrs Logan’s packed lunch which is resting lightly on my tummy. Apparently there was a bit of a surprise when the new Base Commander’s shuttle ran into a meteor cloud or something, but I’m told he’s quite safe. A cynic might think that the poor fellow was trying to get out of watching the contest. Surely not. Anyway, I believe the Neutral Arbiter has just docked.
Ah, that really suits you, Mel. You look good in epaulettes.
Mmm. Amere ensign, though, Commander. Listen, I think I'll make my way to the science lab, find out if they've made any progress with the Tardis.
Good idea.
Beep.
Oh, is that me or you?
It’s you. See you later. Don’t get involved.
Door opens and closes.
Ah, hello, this is the Do... Commander. Can I help you?
[OC]: Commander Ballard. I’m sorry to disturb you, sir, but your presence is urgently required on the Command Deck.
Oh, right, yes. I'll be right up. (beep) Mel did warn me not to get involved, but getting involved is my stock-in-trade, and it is a very nice uniform which I must show off to someone.
Hello? Professor Fassbinder?
Oh, hello, young lady.
Melanie. Known as Mel.
And how can I help you, Mel?
Well. Oh, excuse me, but what are you doing? It looks very interesting.
Oh, this? Er, it’s a device for er, for measuring proton strings in the twelfth dimension.
I see. Well, no, I don’t. Why are you doing that?
Why? Er, to er, to see if the er, if the proton strings behave differently under, under a different set of er dimensions, of course.
Oh. What have you discovered so far?
I just er don’t know. The wave equations are very, very complex.
I could give you a hand. No, hold on. Mustn’t get involved. And it’s all over my head. What I came to ask was, did you find anything in the debris of the shuttle?
No, nothing as yet. Er, I’ve set the data calibrators to the widest possible three hundred and sixty degree sweeps, So, 000, it’ll take a little longer.
Well, be sure to give either the Commander or me a call when, if anything turns up. I'll leave you to your proton strings.
Yes.
Mel leaves.
Well, Melanie, known as Mel, I don’t like little girls who ask too many questions.
Please madam, sit down.
This is a deliberate insult to the people of Angvia.
You'll get nowhere if you shout.
Is that your philosophy? No shouting! No surprise you’re all such weaklings on this side of the galaxy.
The Commander is on his way. Ah, here he is now.
Ah, I've finally found my way back. Now, how can I help you?
Commander
I have been placed in quarters right next to Gholos. This is either incompetence or a gross and deliberate insult.
Ah, don’t worry. I’m sure it was just incompetence. It usually is with us humans.
Here’s the accommodation plan, Commander.
Ah yes, I see the problem. Now, why don’t you move here?
Next to Cyrene?
Ah, yes.
After all the insults heaped on my people earlier?
All right. Next to Earth?
Ha! So you can spy on me?
Next to er
Do not go on, Commander. All your suggestions are equally ludicrous. You obviously have as little idea about conference management as you do about flying a shuttle!
Really. That’s most
Where’s Mel with that whistle? Ah, Mel. No, not Mel. Not Mel at all. Some sort of pipe-y rodent thing.
Oh, what a relief. Commander Ballard, Queen Angvia, let me introduce you to the Neutral Arbiter of the song contest.
Ah, hello, Miss er. Don’t I know you?
(high pitched) I believe to Earth creatures we Pakhars all look the same.
Sounds exactly like Cyrene — same actress.
Pakhars, of course!
Commander, let me introduce Geri Pakhar.
A pleasure. Eek.
Ah. Oh, there aren’t any buttons. There must be some way of getting this thing working. Er
Guest rooms.
Turbolift operates.
Oh, well done. I don’t have much luck with lifts.
Look, just give me whatever you want signed and I'll sign it.
What? What do you mean? I
Fine. Forget it, then. Your loss.
So, are you here for the contest, or do you work here?
Don’t you know who I am?
I’m afraid not.
Really? You really don’t know who I am?
I’m new to these parts.
But I’m the fifth most famous person in the galaxy, as voted by the readers of Entropy Magazine.
I’m sorry.
Sorry?
I don’t really keep up with all the celebrity gossip.
What’s your name?
Melanie. Known as Mel. And you are?
And you are? And you are? I can’t remember the last time anybody asked me my name. Come here.
Kiss.
Oh. (giggles)
Now, I’m sure we can sort everything out quite amicably. Pass me the accommodation plan, Lieutenant. (Lef-tenant)
Loo-tenant.
Oh yes, sorry. Now, where are we? Madam, I will move you here, if that’s all right.
I suppose it is acceptable.
As long as the Breebles don’t mind switching rooms
I am sure they will see the problem and be keen to help out any way they can.
There we are. Everything sorted out, nice and ship-shape. Now then
Door opens.
Commander, I must protest.
Oh no.
Gholos is enraged.
Oh, really? I’d never have guessed.
Our quarters are directly next to
No, they are not. The Commander has seen the gross insult of placing me next to you, and assigned me a room at the far end of the block.
Gholos is very angry, Commander. It is he who should have been moved away from her.
Yes, well, first come first served, as we say on Earth. Now, how about you two going back to your rooms and preparing for the contest.
I will be happy to, now I do not have the stench of Gholos under my nose.
Gholos?
Under protest.
I'd better get back to the medical unit. Well handled, Commander, or may I call you John?
Eh? Oh yes, of course, Elaine.
Eleanor.
Eleanor.
Walking.
At last, someone I can have a proper conversation with. Somebody who knows as little about me as I know about them. Listen, don’t rush off. Have you got a few minutes?
All the time in the world. Literally.
Let me tell you all about myself. No, I mean, you tell me all about yourself.
I'll try. Er, what is your name?
What is your name. What is your name. I love it.
Please.
Nicky Newman. Great!
What?
Well, for a moment there I was afraid you’d say, oh, that Nicky Newman, the pop star.
No, really, I haven’t the faintest idea who you are.
Me? I’m just a bloke. (laughs) Just a bloke.
Now, where was I?
Would you sign these reports, sir?
Yes, of course. John Ballard. Thank you.
: Sir.
Hmm. Is this my chair? Very comfy. And all these buttons.
Commander?
Hmm?
I very much admired your handling of the earlier situation. You were almost Pakhar-like in your diplomacy.
Yes, I suppose I was quite impressive, wasn’t I?

Citizens of Gholos and Angvia rarely meet. When they come face to face, as it were, it can be very unpleasant and undiplomatic. At this delicate time, we must all beware the tensions between Gholos and Angvia.
Ah yes, the Peace Conference on Achilles Four.
Geri sighs.
You seem a little troubled.

Oh, Commander, my sister is an observer at the conference. I couldn’t help but be a little worried when I saw those two tearing strips off each other. Poor Teri, on the other side of space, having to cope with hordes of Angvians and Gholosians. At least we only have two on our hands. Oh, why can’t all the races of the galaxy live in peace like the people of my planet?
That’s what makes you such good diplomats. You know, I don’t think I’ve ever visited Pakhar.

It is a place of serenity and tranquillity, Commander. We Pakhars are content to trade, work, and relax in utter harmony. All is calm. No voices are raised. Nothing but the gentle turning of our work wheels and the sighing of the waves as they lap the distant shores.
Alarm sounds.
Ah, you were asking for that. What is it, Lieutenant?
An alarm, sir.
I guessed that. What about?
It, it’s coming from the guest rooms, sir.
Quick, Arbiter.
Oh dear, what now?
What is it?
It’s an alarm.
I know that. I meant, what’s it in aid of?
It’s coming from down here.
Come on, then. Let’s take a look.
Running.
This is my cabin. It’s coming from next door. That’s Cyrene’s room.
Help me get this door open. (knocks) Hello? Hello? Are you all right in there?
Door opens.
Oh, no. I don’t like the look of this. How do we get the lights on?
Over here.
Lights on.
Oh God. She’s had some sort of accident.
I don’t know much about Cyrene metabolism, but I think she’s dead.
Oh no.
And you only have to look at her face to see that this was no accident. We have to face facts, Nicky. There’s a murderer loose aboard Dark Space Eight.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
ELEANOR: Dark Space Eight, status report. Day 4,814 of operation. Chief Medic Eleanor Harcourt reporting. We are gradually beginning to overcome our grief at the loss of Commander Keel. The subdued mood in the corridors of the station among the 210 men and women of the crew is beginning to lift. Our new mission orders have been received, and we await the arrival of our new commander in an atmosphere of cool serenity and undisturbed tranquillity.
ELEANOR: Oh, I’m so sorry. I accidentally hit the Red Alert switch there. (alarm stops) Sorry, everyone. Our new commander will take the helm of Dark Space Eight on a crucial mission at a crucial moment in the history of the whole galaxy. End of status report.
IVOR: Well done, Eleanor. The Commander’s death has hit us all for six, but I know how close you were.
ELEANOR: I can’t help feeling responsible, Ivor.
IVOR: Oh, there’s not much that anybody, even a top medic like you, can do about the Orion flu.
ELEANOR: True. But I could have stopped him going off to confront that silicon-based entity in the first place.

GERI: Oh, Commander, my sister is an observer at the conference. I couldn’t help but be a little worried when I saw those two tearing strips off each other. Poor Teri, on the other side of space, having to cope with hordes of Angvians and Gholosians. At least we only have two on our hands. Oh, why can’t all the races of the galaxy live in peace like the people of my planet?
DOCTOR: That’s what makes you such good diplomats. You know, I don’t think I’ve ever visited Pakhar.
GERI: It is a place of serenity and tranquillity, Commander. We Pakhars are content to trade, work, and relax in utter harmony. All is calm. No voices are raised. Nothing but the gentle turning of our work wheels and the sighing of the waves as they lap the distant shores.
DOCTOR: Ah, you were asking for that. What is it, Lieutenant?
STRINDBERG: An alarm, sir.
DOCTOR: I guessed that. What about?
STRINDBERG: It, it’s coming from the guest rooms, sir.
DOCTOR: Quick, Arbiter.
GERI: Oh dear, what now?
MEL: What is it?
NICKY: It’s an alarm.
MEL: I know that. I meant, what’s it in aid of?
NICKY: It’s coming from down here.
MEL: Come on, then. Let’s take a look.
NICKY: This is my cabin. It’s coming from next door. That’s Cyrene’s room.
MEL: Help me get this door open. (knocks) Hello? Hello? Are you all right in there?
MEL: Oh, no. I don’t like the look of this. How do we get the lights on?
NICKY: Over here.
NICKY: Oh God. She’s had some sort of accident.
MEL: I don’t know much about Cyrene metabolism, but I think she’s dead.
NICKY: Oh no.
MEL: And you only have to look at her face to see that this was no accident. We have to face facts, Nicky. There’s a murderer loose aboard Dark Space Eight.

elements.text: [Part Two]
I heard the alarm. Oh, my God. Please, stand away. I must examine her.
It looks like she pressed the alarm and then collapsed.
God, that alarm is really getting on my nerves. How do we switch it off?
There’s a dead body in the room, and you prioritise the alarm?
Alarm stops.
Actually, I was trying not to think about the dead body, thanks.
I’m afraid there’s nothing I can do for her. I feel so helpless.
How did she die? She looks terrified.
It’s hard to tell, but there are no abrasions or contusions. Without a thorough medical scan I can’t make a full diagnosis, but it looks to be natural causes.
What?
What has happened? Oh no.
Eleanor, is she
I’m afraid so. She’s dead, John.
Let me see.
Oh, this is awful. Awful. Oh, Nicky Newman! (giggles.)
Oh, God.
Whatever was all the commotion... oh, no.
It’s like Piccadilly Circus in here.
What has happened to the Cyrene contestant, Doctor?
Well, you see that er. Oh, I think er, she was talking to you.
What? Oh, there’s really no cause for panic. At the moment I cannot identify the precise cause of Cyrene’s death, but I think we can rule out foul play.
The Doctor and Mel groan.
What a relief!
I’m afraid not. Look at these marks.
Those? I assumed they were part of Cyrene’s distinctive colouring.
Decidedly not. Poison, I fancy.
Groans.
Poison? Oh, no.
I suggest you take a sample for analysis, Doctor Harcourt.
Of course.
And I further suggest that we leave the Doctor to her work, and reconvene in the rest room.
The rest room?
I mean the er guest lounge.
Look, everyone, I think we need to relax and take stock. We still don’t know for sure that Cyrene was poisoned.
Could you pass me the nuts, please?
Marvellous. One of the contestants has just been murdered, and all the Neutral Arbiter can think about is nuts.
I always snack when I’m nervous. Actually, I don’t know whether I’m more nervous about the murder or meeting Nicky. (giggles)
Oh, God.
Please, calm down, Mister Loozly.
Cyrene is an old ally of Gholos. Gholos is adamant Cyrene was murdered by Angvia.
Commander cannot listen to these ravings and these ramblings.
Look, you two, can’t you calm it down a bit?
Who is this Earth creature? Ah, it is Nicky Newman. Greetings from Angvia.
This is only a song contest, for goodness’ sakes.
Gholos thinks the contest should be cancelled immediately.
Cancelled?
No, that’s out of the question. We don’t want to send out the wrong signals, especially not with that Peace Conference in session. Now everybody, calm down.
Come on, Mister LooZly, sit down and have a drink.
Certainly not.
Oh, take a break. Get a bit of human company for a change.
The company of Gholos is more than adequate. Gholos wishes me to compose a strongly worded official letter of complaint. Good day. (leaves)
Cretinous man, to want to spend his life with those hideous creatures.
The people of Gholos deserve our respect.
They are killers! Thirty generations ago, their raiding parties descended from the skies onto our peaceful pastoral settlements. We were forced to become warriors merely in order to survive.
Well, it takes two to foxtrot.

You know nothing of our history, Commander. None of you do. Have you ever seen somebody by one of Gholos? It is hideous. The creature glows blue, it crackles with hatred, it stinks. Do you want to die like that? Be on your guard, all of you. (leaves)
Hold on. Are all of you thinking what I’m thinking?
The blue sting of Gholos
Could have killed Cyrene.
Nonsense. It’s very dangerous to speculate. Eleanor will provide an answer. Until she does, careless talk, and all that.
It’s what I’ve always feared. The contest could become a grudge match, a chance to try and settle old scores.
Actually, Miss Pakhar.
Yes, Professor?
I’m rather surprised to see you here. Isn’t it a bit of a come-down for one of the great Pakhars to be overseeing a mere song contest?

Certainly not. I treat this appointment as prestigious in the extreme. I’m sorry to find that some of the staff of Dark Space Eight don’t appear to share my view. I think I shall go to my cabin. Huh. (leaves)
Huh. Sniffy lot, these Pakhars. Can one of you pass the wine?
Oh no, I’ve just realised.
What?
I’m meant to be doing a subspace interview in ten minutes. I'd better get off. Look, don’t slip away. You still haven't told me all about yourself.
It won’t take long. I’m hardly famous or interesting.
Exactly. I’ve had enough of famous interesting people.
And if you'll excuse me, Commander, I must get back to the lab, see if anything has come through on the er scan of your shuttle.
Very well.
Ivor leaves.
Alone at last.
Look at you.
What?
You're loving every minute of this, aren’t you, Commander?
Until we can get the Tardis back, we’ve got to play along. Unless you fancy a lot of tedious being locked up, accused, and interrogated?
And playing Poirot has got nothing to do with it?
Someone killed Commander Ballard, and someone, possibly the same someone, killed the Cyrene. Why?
At the risk of repeating myself, none of our business.
Come on, Mel. Every Poirot needs his Watson.
Hastings.
Lovely place. What about it?
Oh, I despair. Okay, I can play the side-kick. What do you want me to do?
Cyrene’s quarters. Clues. And I'd better get back to the Command Deck.
Oh ho, welcome back. I’ve just had a note to say that the entry from Cyrene has had to drop out due to ill health. Get well soon, Cyrene.
[OC]: Well, only another few hours to go, and things are beginning to get interesting here.
You’re right there. Now then. Hello, is that you, Eleanor?
[OC]: Yes, John.
Any progress on those tests?
[OC]: Not so far. The substance I took from Cyrene is very hard to identify.
Keep trying, Eleanor. Commander out.
Door opens.
Ah, Professor Fassbinder.
Door closes.
Commander. I’ve got the results of the sensor scan.
Oh yes, let’s have a look.
Nothing very interesting, I’m afraid. Certainly nothing that could explain the explosion. Just a lot of rock.
You didn’t find any large objects? Anything unusual?
No, it’s all there in the report. Just a lot of atomised rock and a cloud of fuel cells. Still don’t know what caused the er
Never mind that. I mean, you did a full scan?
Yes.
And found no large objects? Nothing like a tall blue box with a light on top?
With a light on top? No, no, nothing like that at all.
Oh, no.
Door opens.
Hello? Anyone there? No? Good. Let’s get sniffing for clues.
Door closes.
Er, dressing table. Nothing. Under the bed? No.
Door opens.
Oh, hello.
Door closes.
Er, I was just looking about. The Commander asked me to
Gholos makes his noise.
I’m sorry about what I said earlier. I'm sure the people of Gholos are great company. No, really, I didn’t mean. What are you doing? No. No, keep back. Please, keep away, please. No! No, no.
Gholos? Gholos, are you there?
Help!
What’s going on?
Get it away from me!
Come away, Gholos. This Earth girl is harmless. Yes, I would very much like to know that too. What are you doing here?
What am / doing here? The Commander sent me to examine the room for clues. I didn’t expect to be attacked by your, your fizzy friend.
Yes, yes, I'll explain to her. Melanie, is it? Gholos was doing much the same.
Oh, I don’t think so. Why did he attack?
Gholos thought you were attacking him.
With what?
You must understand. Gholos is naturally suspicious of humanoid females.
I’m hardly a harridan like Angvia.
Gholos regrets the incident.
It doesn’t sound like it. I think you ought to keep that thing under better control.
I do not control Gholos, young lady. And that thing, as you so arrogantly put it, is part of the most advanced entity in the cosmos. Certainly more advanced than a mere human like you.
Or indeed you.
That is to my eternal regret. Come, Gholos. Our apologies for this misunderstanding.
He sounds pretty steamed up.
To be blunt, he is outraged at your slanders. He wants me to write a sternly worded letter complaining about your conduct.
Door opens.
Mel? Oh, hello, Mel.
Excuse us.
Hey, watch it, Mister Loozly.
Door closes.
What’s he so steamed up about? You all right, Mel? Thought I could hear you, finished my interview. Thought we could have our chat, go for a swim? What’s going on? You look a bit shaken up.
Nicky, that creature, it tried to kill me.
But Ivor, what actually befell the Commander’s shuttle?

I just don’t know, Eleanor. Perhaps some freak effect. Magnetic space lightning, cloud of invisible particles. Or some kind of new alien energy that just doesn’t show up on our scanners. I just don’t know.
Commander, you look troubled.
I’m fine, really.
The object you lost, it was of sentimental value?
Irreplaceable.
I'm sorry. If you ever need to talk, the door to my quarters is always open, John.
Er, oh, thank you.
I was able to be of great personal comfort to Commander Keel.
Oh, yes, I'll bear that in mind.
Commander?
What is it, Lieutenant Strindberg?
I’m picking up alarming reports on the space news channels.
Oh, switch it on. I mean, patch them through.
Aye, sir.

[OC]: Terrorist ships have broken through the security cordon, the so-called ring of iron around Achilles Four, and all fortified SSTs. The Achilles Four interceptors engaged with the first wave with limited success, but now the second wave of fighters have struck from delta sector.
[OC]: And what can you see from where you're standing, Brian?
[OC]: It’s just
Achilles Four is under attack.
I think we’ve heard enough, Lieutenant.
This is terrible. That station was brand new. It was supposed to be impregnable.
Nothing’s impregnable if you have the right equipment. Or the right information.
This was the last best hope for peace between Gholos and Angvia.
Yes, if the Achilles Four conference fails, war rages on forever.
If only we could do something. Oh, I feel so helpless.
We can do something.
What?

Our bit. We keep our peckers up, we put our shoulders to the wheel, our noses to the grindstone, our backs to the trough and our elbows in the grease, to make sure this Intergalactic Song Contest is the best the universe has ever seen, or will ever see. We show the warmakers that music can bring harmony.
Let’s do the show right here, in the barn.
Don't be so cynical, Mel.

And it appears Achilles Four has been attacked by Angvian separatists. Oh dear. You have to ask yourself, what’s going through the minds of these people? Well, I suppose it’s back to the contest. Something to cheer us all up. Or not. The arena’s just beginning to fill up. Let me just describe the arena to you. The seating holds forty thousand specially invited audience members. What an honour to be invited, eh? And there they are, enjoying the hospitality, staggering back to their seats. There are two hundred thousand mini- crystal hovercams covering every angle of the performance space, beaming every detail of each song to a quinquillion homes across the universe. Ah yes, you can bet it’s going to be an unforgettable night.
What do you mean, they can’t find the Tardis?
It’s not showing up on their scans, so the Professor says.
Perhaps it’s floated off somewhere.
Impossible.
Or it really did get blown up.
Equally impossible. The Tardis is impregnable. Oh.
What?
Nothing. But the Tardis is indestructible, ergo, it must be out there.
Ergo their scanners are playing up. Or
Ergo?
The Professor is lying. You know, I thought there was something odd about him.
There’s something odd about plenty of people. It doesn’t make them liars. But it certainly adds to the mystery.
And I’ve got yet another piece of that jigsaw.
Yes?
Gholos attacked me in Cyrene’s room. Loozly called it off, and it said it was just looking for clues same as me, but it was glowing bright red and looked furious.
Oh, Mel, are you all right?

Ah, you know me, Doctor. Takes more than a stroppy alien to shake me up. How would I cope with you otherwise? I reckon Professor Fassbinder and Gholos are in this together. He blew up the shuttle, and Gholos killed Cyrene, and tried to kill me to cover up the evidence.
Brilliant.
What?
An astonishing display.
Really?
Of leaping to hasty conclusions. You’ve no evidence to support your theory.
I suppose not. But have you got any evidence to disprove it?
Not yet. I suggest we keep our eyes peeled, our ears pricked and our other sensory appendages primed.
I have been.
Really? Oh, you’ve already missed something important.
What?
When we discovered Cyrene
What?
Ah.
Oh no, Doctor, spill the beans.
Unlike you, Mel, I won’t spill my beans until I Know how many of them make five.
Eh?
Come in!
Door opens.
Excuse me, Commander. Sorry to disturb you in your ready room, but your presence is requested in the contestant’s lounge. There’s some kind of disturbance.
No prizes for guessing who that it.
Those terrorists are not affiliated to the Angvian State. They have no connection with the Angvian State. They do not represent the species of the Angvian State.
This is a deliberate attempt to destroy the peace process, to besmirch the good name of Gholos by provoking a walk-out by the Gholos delegation. A flagrant breach of trust by the Angvian delegation.
Stop, stop, just stop it! This contest is designed to create an atmosphere of harmony between all races. It is not political.
At this time, every act is a political act.
These people are terrorists. They want to provoke war and aggression between us. If we argue we will be giving them exactly what they want. We must strive to rise above their provocation.
I couldn’t have put it better myself.
Hi, Mel. That’s the Commander?
And you must be Nicky Newman?
You don’t know me either? Oh, fantastic.
Now, Mister Loozly. Melanie has explained what happened just now.
Gholos attacked me, that’s what.
He did no such thing.
And we are happy to accept your apologies.
I am not
We are all happy to accept your apologies!
I wish it would stop fizzing like that. It’s making me feel ill.
Gholos is naturally anxious. First the murder of Cyrene, now the attack on Achilles Four. The contest should be called off.
That is out of the question. Please, try to remain calm.
Yes. It’s time for everyone to stop getting so red in the face. Including you, Gholos.
Gholos only turns this colour in a time of extreme crisis.

Crisis? What crisis? Please, Gholos, you are safe. And while I command Dark Space Eight, you will come to no harm. I’m going to assign er security patrols to all area, and I'll put the station on full alert. But
the contest is most definitely going ahead. Ah, Eleanor.
Commander. I’ve got the results of the tests on Cyrene’s body.
Now we will know the truth, the blue sting of Gholos.
The results are inconclusive. Cyrene died from a massive internal haemorrhage, a sudden and tremendous shock to the neuro-cortex the brain.
Let me see those scans.
It’s impossible to tell what caused that shock.
What about the marks on the skin?
There’s no way of telling what could have the scarring on the tissue, or whether it’s even connected to the neural spasm.
Right. So everybody can just calm down and focus on the contest.
Hear, hear.
This is typical human behaviour, burying your heads in the sand. Come, Gholos. (leaves)
You do well, Commander. Very well. Now, I trust you will respect the customs of my people and, before the contest, you will dine with me.
Er, naturally.
Good. I will see you in the dining sphere at 1800 hours.
It will be a pleasure.
I’m sure it will. (leaves)
Phew. I don’t envy you, Commander.
It is an Angvian tradition to take a meal with the chief of the village they are visiting. I hope you don’t mind, Commander?
Not at all. I’m feeling rather peckish. Now then. Ah. Oh, isn’t it quiet all of a sudden. Perhaps it’s a good time for us all to have a rest.
Come on in, Mel, the water’s lovely.
Splash.
It’s freezing!
Yeah, I was lying. The heating must have packed up like everything else on this station.
The way the Professor and Eleanor talk, you’d think the place was a hot-bed of adventure.

Once, maybe. I mean, my mum was really made up that I was coming to Dark Space Eight, because it used to be in the news all the time. You know, invasions foiled, all that bit. Look, are you coming in or not?
Okay, okay, here goes. (splash) Ah! It’s even colder in here than I
Don’t be such a baby.
(shivering) Oh, don’t worry about me. I seem to spend my whole life being wet and cold. Er, being a pilot, I mean.
Right. So how did you get into that, then?
Oh, you know, the usual way. I mean, it’s nowhere near as exciting as what you do.
Don’t you believe it. Everybody thinks that. All I ever get is, aren’t you lucky. Well, when they can actually manage to speak to me instead of just staring and dribbling.
That’s the price of fame, I suppose.

Yeah. But everybody thinks they know me, and everybody has an opinion about me. Can you imagine what that’s like? I haven’t even met most of them. But even when I do, people think I’ve said too much, or I haven’t said enough, or I’m being over-friendly, or not friendly enough, or that I’m too aloof, or that I’m trying too hard to be down to earth. Honestly, Mel, it drives me mad. I was sitting on that shuttle here, all the flight crew muttering about me, screaming fans floating over my shoulder, feeling like death, my head thumping.
Well, I suppose you

It was only that Mister Loozly who was polite enough to ask me how I was. And that’s only because he’s been living in candyfloss land for years. I had to cadge a headache pill off him because I couldn’t face another round of giggling from the stewardess. And I mean, have you any idea how sick I feel right now, knowing I’ve got to go on in front of God knows how many billion people and sing? Don’t get me started on how the media portray me, because. Oh God. Look, I’m sorry. Listen to me. Poor little rich boy.
So why don’t you give it up? You could walk away, couldn’t you? Go home.
Are you mad? My manager would kill me. And my mum. And as for the fans.
But you can’t live your life for other people.
Would Mister White please come to the media-sphere. (repeats under)
Oh God, not again.
Hmm?
Mister White. That’s me. It’s what they call me so that people won't follow me about, or send a paparazzi-cam after me. Must be another fan club chat or something. Christ, I’m sick of this.
Gets out of pool.
Well, take my advice then, and
You just don’t get it, do you? Don’t even try to understand cos you can't. I’ve got to go. Laters.
Hey, I was only trying to help. What’s got into him?

Well, the band’s tuning up, the guests are supping up, and the acts are giving up. Any ideas of doing a runner, that is. As for me, well, I’m keeping meself busy whilst we wait for tonight’s festivities to kick off. Now, I get a lot of letters, surprising though that may seem, and some of them even ask me sensible questions. Some of the ones I can read, that is. Ha, ha. Now, some of you have been wondering how I can comment on the songs when I can’t even say the names of half of them. Good question, there. Well, this year I’ve got something to beat my critics with, and it isn’t a stick this time.

[OC]: No, old Logan isn’t quite as stupid as he seems, as I’ve been working on me own little translator unit for the last couple of months. And if the lure of the hospitality bar isn’t too great, I’m hoping to have it ready in time for the contest. That way, I can give ‘em all a fair chance before I stamp all over them. (laughs) Anyways, I'll hand you over now to Burt Swanley and the Debonaires, who thought they might inflict a little bit of real music on you all before we get down to business. This is Logan singing off for now.
Someone has been sighing and tutting through that speech.
Hello? Oh, Mister Loozly. Is your er friend not about?

Gholos is not my friend. Don’t be ridiculous. He’s resting in his cabin. With this device, he can summon me when required, and I can monitor his vital signs. Life away from the gestalt is trying for him. Satisfied?
Right. Good. I’ve just had a swim. It’s good for the heart, you know. Especially in water that cold.
How fascinating.
Don’t they have swimming pools on Gholos’s planet?
The world of Gholos is in many ways, I am sure, beyond your comprehension, young lady.
I’ve been to a lot of strange places.
You talk a lot too.
It’s called being sociable.
Oh, forgive me. I’m not used to other humans.
I think you'll find they’re called people.
Hello, Commander.
You must have some human friends, Mister Loozly?

I worked in Earth Security for several years. I still keep in touch with some of the people there, I suppose. That’s how I first came to visit Gholos, on a diplomatic mission some oh, twenty years ago now.
I hear it’s a bit misty.
Misty?
Yes.

Gholos is oneness, a myriad of shifting colours, some you wouldn't even recognise. The stream of thought that surrounds the gestalt is serene, beautiful. Beings of pure mental energy, creatures of thought, souls, you might say. Can you imagine what that feels like? Not to have to drag this carcase with its needs, its hunger, its incessant demands around with you.
I quite like my carcase, actually
(laughs) I didn’t really think you’d understand, but, Melanie, I really am happy there.
As long as you’re happy, Mister Loozly. Mel, we must get back to the Command Deck, and keep an eye on that space battle.
I'll be up in a minute.
The Doctor leaves.
So, tell me more about what you do when you're with the gestalt.
Well, if you’re really interested about the er
[OC]: We've been hearing rumours all afternoon, Brian, so is there anything you can tell us at this stage?

[OC]: Er, well, there has been no official statement as yet, but just a few moments ago I saw the last of the terrorist ships make hyperjump, with the fleet in hot pursuit. So, as far as any of us can tell, the attack on Achilles Four is now ovet..
[OC]: So the conference seems to be safe.
[OC]: That’s certainly the feeling here, Michael, and given the casualties the attackers suffered, I think it’s safe to say that a second attack is unlikely
[OC]: There’s been a lot said here about the pincer attack the terrorist ships adopted. Can you tell us any more about that?
[OC]: Er, well, er, certainly from where I was sitting their tactics seemed very weak
I think weak might be something of an understatement.
Commander?
Hmm? Oh, nothing, Lieutenant. Nothing. Just talking to myself. Terrible habit of mine. Anyway, it
looks like the Peace Conference had a lucky escape.
It’s lucky for us all.
Indeed, indeed. I wonder if you might do me a favour, Lieutenant, and pop across the way to tell Eleanor. I know how worried she is.
Of course, sir. Right away.
Door opens.
Oh, sorry.
After you, Miss. Please excuse me.
Door closes.
Ah, Pilot Mel. Been having fun?
I actually had quite a nice chat with our Mister LoozZly.
Really?
Mmm. He isn't half as fierce away from that Gholos thing. I just don’t think he’s very good with humans.
(laughs) And I’ve no doubt he received the full Melanie Bush course in people skills.
Gratis and for nothing. So what have you been up to whilst oh. What was that?
Over there, under the door. It’s a note.
Door opens.
Nobody around. Hello? Who's there? Hello?
Curiouser and curiouser.
Door closes.
What’s it say?
Commander. Beware the pits of Angvia.
No name?
Nothing.
The pits of Angvia? What’s that supposed to mean?
Pits? I don’t remember there being any pits on Angvia. Very big trees, as I recall, but no pits. And anyway, the planet’s halfway across space from here.
Or maybe it’s meant to throw us. You know, send us off on a wild goose chase.
But it’s meaningless. I mean, if you wanted to befuddle someone, you’d make up something more cryptic, less specific.
Well, whoever left it obviously wants to implicate our friendly neighbourhood Valkyrie in this mess. I mean, it could have been Lieutenant Strindberg. He was close by, and he
Oh, Mel.

Sorry. But someone left it. Hey. Perhaps it was the Professor. I mean, we don’t know what sort of devices he could have hidden in here. Maybe he heard us talking earlier and decided to shift the blame.

Maybe, maybe not. Maybe it was Eleanor, or Loozly, or Nicky, or Geri, or old Mister Jenkins the Janitor. I could go on all afternoon and it still wouldn’t get us anywhere. The only people we can rule out are you and me. Unless there’s something you're not telling me?
Oh, very funny. Well, I still think it’s a good theory. And I’m going to go have a nose round the Professor’s lab. If nothing else, it might mean we can cross off a suspect.
Professor Fassbinder, with the lead piping in the lab. Oh, all right then. But be careful.
I’m not the one who needs to be careful. You’ve got a date with Angvia.
There you are, Mister Newman. These drugs should help with your headache and nausea.
I don’t like the look of them. What are they?
They're an extract of Malvolian fungoid.
Wish I hadn’t asked.
Have you taken any other drugs in the last twenty four hours?
I had an aspirin on the shuttle.
Well, these shouldn't react adversely with that.
They smell funny. Mel? Hey, Mel?
Oh, it’s you. What do you want? I’m busy.
Look, I’m sorry we had that little row, or spat, or whatever it was.
I wasn’t aware that we’d had a row. As I recall, I was trying to be helpful and you were shouting at me.
Oh. Yeah. Sorry. Friends?
Yes, okay. I could do with some help.
Oh, really? With what, exactly?
Oh, never mind. It’s nothing important. Come on, Nicky.
Yeah, coming. Thanks for the pills, Doc.
What? Oh, yes, yes. Mmm.
Restaurant chatter and clinking of glasses.
Yes, if I could just squeeze past?
Ah, Commander. I was beginning to fear you were not coming.
Oh, I never break a date.
And I have never been, how do you say on Earth, stood down? Do you wish to see the menu?
Oh, thank you.
Good evening, sir, madam. May I take your order?
Oh yes. Yes, I'll have a Pamperanian fritters to start with.
I will not have a starter. We of Angvia do not have starters. I’m interested only in the main course.
Oh. In which case then
Rump of Argelian Starbison, rare.
Er, twice, please.
Very good, sir, madam.
Well, er
Well.
Well, here we are.
Yes. We are here.
Here we are, then.
Yes.
We’re agreed on that, anyway. My old philosopher friend Descartes could never decide if he was here or not. Played havoc when it came to working out the bill.
(laughs hysterically) Oh, Commander. Oh, you are so, so witty! My, but it’s warm in here. I’ll just remove my helmet.
Clunk.
Ooo, your hair.
What of it?
Well, it’s very lovely. I mean, it’s very long.
Do Earth women also have lovely hair?

Er, yes, yes, I suppose so. I’ve never really thought about it. Strange. So, your people have been at war with Gholos for a very long time. How did it all get started, anyway? I’m rather vague on the details.
It’s all ancient history. It does not matter tonight.
All these border incursions seem to be
Politics. Ah, no, it is a bore. I know little of such matters. We learn the worst of the crimes by rote at the seminar, but I was always an entertainer in my heart and soul.
Yes. Er, nice view.
The wall?
Well, it’s quite a nice wall.
No, it is not.
I don’t suppose it is.
Forgive me, Commander. I must be blunt with you.
Be as blunt as you like.
Ever since we met, I have felt something inside me, stirring.
You should go to the sickbay.
Sickbay? Ha. Doctors cannot cure love.
Love?
You act as if you’ve never heard the word before.
Well, I’ve heard of it, but perhaps you’re having a bit of a difficulty with our language.
No. I said love. I mean love.
Er, what sort of love do you mean? Professional admiration? Platonic affection? Quite liking someone in a distant abstract sort of way?
I am talking of mad passionate love! Embraces under the stars. On Angvia we women choose our mates.
Sort of like a ladies’ excuse-me kind of thing.
I know nothing of this ladies’ excuse-me. All I know is what my heart tells me. I look into your eyes and I see boiling masculine virility under the flimsy lid of your beauty.
Do you?
Come here!
Argh!
Rest your head on my bosom. You hear my heart pounding?
(muffled) Mmph.
Feel it?
(muffled) Yes. It’s actually rather comfortable.
Now, do you feel love?
What? I. Yes. Yes, strangely enough, I think I’m beginning to
So why are we looking for the Professor?
Shh. We’re not. We’re just going for a little nose round his lab.
But, won't he mind?
If we’re careful, he’ll never know. Professor? Professor Fassbinder, are you there? Great. It’s lucky he never seems to be around. Come on, and be careful.
We shouldn’t be doing this, Mel. The tabloids’ll have a field day if I get wrapped up in, well, I don’t know, breaking and entering or whatever it is we’re doing.
All the more reason to shut up and start looking around.
What for?
I don’t know. Clues. Anything suspicious. This is a murder investigation, remember. Look for something murderous.
All right, all right. (beeps) Whoa!
Shh!
Sorry. What was that?
Door opens.
Hmm?
Someone’s coming.
What? You’re right. Quick, behind this thing.
Door closes. Whispering.
Who is it? Can you see?
I don’t recognise him.
Let me see. It’s Logan, the commentator. He interviewed me once.
You don’t suppose he’s mixed up in all this?
Him? No, he can’t be.
Who’s there? Who, who, who
He’s found us. I’d better come clean. (normal) Mister Logan? Er, hello. My name’s Mel. I’m here with Nicky Newman.
Hi.
We were just waiting for Professor Fassbinder to come back and er
Logan groans.
Are you all right? What’s wrong?
Oh no. Oh no, is that
Oh, Mister Logan? Mister Logan?
This is Logan, signing off.
Nicky, at the risk of making a habit out of this kind of thing, he’s dead. He’s been stabbed in the back!

parts.searchable_dialogue:
ELEANOR: I heard the alarm. Oh, my God. Please, stand away. I must examine her.
MEL: It looks like she pressed the alarm and then collapsed.
NICKY: God, that alarm is really getting on my nerves. How do we switch it off?
MEL: There’s a dead body in the room, and you prioritise the alarm?
NICKY: Actually, I was trying not to think about the dead body, thanks.
ELEANOR: I’m afraid there’s nothing I can do for her. I feel so helpless.
MEL: How did she die? She looks terrified.
ELEANOR: It’s hard to tell, but there are no abrasions or contusions. Without a thorough medical scan I can’t make a full diagnosis, but it looks to be natural causes.
MEL: What?
GERI: What has happened? Oh no.
DOCTOR: Eleanor, is she
ELEANOR: I’m afraid so. She’s dead, John.
DOCTOR: Let me see.
GERI: Oh, this is awful. Awful. Oh, Nicky Newman! (giggles.)
NICKY: Oh, God.
IVOR: Whatever was all the commotion... oh, no.
MEL: It’s like Piccadilly Circus in here.
GERI: What has happened to the Cyrene contestant, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Well, you see that er. Oh, I think er, she was talking to you.
ELEANOR: What? Oh, there’s really no cause for panic. At the moment I cannot identify the precise cause of Cyrene’s death, but I think we can rule out foul play.
GERI: What a relief!
DOCTOR: I’m afraid not. Look at these marks.
ELEANOR: Those? I assumed they were part of Cyrene’s distinctive colouring.
DOCTOR: Decidedly not. Poison, I fancy.
GERI: Poison? Oh, no.
DOCTOR: I suggest you take a sample for analysis, Doctor Harcourt.
ELEANOR: Of course.
DOCTOR: And I further suggest that we leave the Doctor to her work, and reconvene in the rest room.
ELEANOR: The rest room?
DOCTOR: I mean the er guest lounge.
MEL: Look, everyone, I think we need to relax and take stock. We still don’t know for sure that Cyrene was poisoned.
GERI: Could you pass me the nuts, please?
IVOR: Marvellous. One of the contestants has just been murdered, and all the Neutral Arbiter can think about is nuts.
GERI: I always snack when I’m nervous. Actually, I don’t know whether I’m more nervous about the murder or meeting Nicky. (giggles)
NICKY: Oh, God.
DOCTOR: Please, calm down, Mister Loozly.
LOOZLY: Cyrene is an old ally of Gholos. Gholos is adamant Cyrene was murdered by Angvia.
ANGVIA: Commander cannot listen to these ravings and these ramblings.
NICKY: Look, you two, can’t you calm it down a bit?
ANGVIA: Who is this Earth creature? Ah, it is Nicky Newman. Greetings from Angvia.
NICKY: This is only a song contest, for goodness’ sakes.
LOOZLY: Gholos thinks the contest should be cancelled immediately.
GERI: Cancelled?
DOCTOR: No, that’s out of the question. We don’t want to send out the wrong signals, especially not with that Peace Conference in session. Now everybody, calm down.
MEL: Come on, Mister LooZly, sit down and have a drink.
LOOZLY: Certainly not.
MEL: Oh, take a break. Get a bit of human company for a change.
LOOZLY: The company of Gholos is more than adequate. Gholos wishes me to compose a strongly worded official letter of complaint. Good day. (leaves)
ANGVIA: Cretinous man, to want to spend his life with those hideous creatures.
DOCTOR: The people of Gholos deserve our respect.
ANGVIA: They are killers! Thirty generations ago, their raiding parties descended from the skies onto our peaceful pastoral settlements. We were forced to become warriors merely in order to survive.
DOCTOR: Well, it takes two to foxtrot.
ANGVIA: You know nothing of our history, Commander. None of you do. Have you ever seen somebody by one of Gholos? It is hideous. The creature glows blue, it crackles with hatred, it stinks. Do you want to die like that? Be on your guard, all of you. (leaves)
NICKY: Hold on. Are all of you thinking what I’m thinking?
GERI: The blue sting of Gholos
IVOR: Could have killed Cyrene.
DOCTOR: Nonsense. It’s very dangerous to speculate. Eleanor will provide an answer. Until she does, careless talk, and all that.
GERI: It’s what I’ve always feared. The contest could become a grudge match, a chance to try and settle old scores.
IVOR: Actually, Miss Pakhar.
GERI: Yes, Professor?
IVOR: I’m rather surprised to see you here. Isn’t it a bit of a come-down for one of the great Pakhars to be overseeing a mere song contest?
GERI: Certainly not. I treat this appointment as prestigious in the extreme. I’m sorry to find that some of the staff of Dark Space Eight don’t appear to share my view. I think I shall go to my cabin. Huh. (leaves)
IVOR: Huh. Sniffy lot, these Pakhars. Can one of you pass the wine?
NICKY: Oh no, I’ve just realised.
MEL: What?
NICKY: I’m meant to be doing a subspace interview in ten minutes. I'd better get off. Look, don’t slip away. You still haven't told me all about yourself.
MEL: It won’t take long. I’m hardly famous or interesting.
NICKY: Exactly. I’ve had enough of famous interesting people.
IVOR: And if you'll excuse me, Commander, I must get back to the lab, see if anything has come through on the er scan of your shuttle.
DOCTOR: Very well.
DOCTOR: Alone at last.
MEL: Look at you.
DOCTOR: What?
MEL: You're loving every minute of this, aren’t you, Commander?
DOCTOR: Until we can get the Tardis back, we’ve got to play along. Unless you fancy a lot of tedious being locked up, accused, and interrogated?
MEL: And playing Poirot has got nothing to do with it?
DOCTOR: Someone killed Commander Ballard, and someone, possibly the same someone, killed the Cyrene. Why?
MEL: At the risk of repeating myself, none of our business.
DOCTOR: Come on, Mel. Every Poirot needs his Watson.
MEL: Hastings.
DOCTOR: Lovely place. What about it?
MEL: Oh, I despair. Okay, I can play the side-kick. What do you want me to do?
DOCTOR: Cyrene’s quarters. Clues. And I'd better get back to the Command Deck.
LOGAN: Oh ho, welcome back. I’ve just had a note to say that the entry from Cyrene has had to drop out due to ill health. Get well soon, Cyrene.
LOGAN: [OC]: Well, only another few hours to go, and things are beginning to get interesting here.
DOCTOR: You’re right there. Now then. Hello, is that you, Eleanor?
ELEANOR: [OC]: Yes, John.
DOCTOR: Any progress on those tests?
ELEANOR: [OC]: Not so far. The substance I took from Cyrene is very hard to identify.
DOCTOR: Keep trying, Eleanor. Commander out.
DOCTOR: Ah, Professor Fassbinder.
IVOR: Commander. I’ve got the results of the sensor scan.
DOCTOR: Oh yes, let’s have a look.
IVOR: Nothing very interesting, I’m afraid. Certainly nothing that could explain the explosion. Just a lot of rock.
DOCTOR: You didn’t find any large objects? Anything unusual?
IVOR: No, it’s all there in the report. Just a lot of atomised rock and a cloud of fuel cells. Still don’t know what caused the er
DOCTOR: Never mind that. I mean, you did a full scan?
IVOR: Yes.
DOCTOR: And found no large objects? Nothing like a tall blue box with a light on top?
IVOR: With a light on top? No, no, nothing like that at all.
DOCTOR: Oh, no.
MEL: Hello? Anyone there? No? Good. Let’s get sniffing for clues.
MEL: Er, dressing table. Nothing. Under the bed? No.
MEL: Oh, hello.
MEL: Er, I was just looking about. The Commander asked me to
MEL: I’m sorry about what I said earlier. I'm sure the people of Gholos are great company. No, really, I didn’t mean. What are you doing? No. No, keep back. Please, keep away, please. No! No, no.
LOOZLY: Gholos? Gholos, are you there?
MEL: Help!
LOOZLY: What’s going on?
MEL: Get it away from me!
LOOZLY: Come away, Gholos. This Earth girl is harmless. Yes, I would very much like to know that too. What are you doing here?
MEL: What am / doing here? The Commander sent me to examine the room for clues. I didn’t expect to be attacked by your, your fizzy friend.
LOOZLY: Yes, yes, I'll explain to her. Melanie, is it? Gholos was doing much the same.
MEL: Oh, I don’t think so. Why did he attack?
LOOZLY: Gholos thought you were attacking him.
MEL: With what?
LOOZLY: You must understand. Gholos is naturally suspicious of humanoid females.
MEL: I’m hardly a harridan like Angvia.
LOOZLY: Gholos regrets the incident.
MEL: It doesn’t sound like it. I think you ought to keep that thing under better control.
LOOZLY: I do not control Gholos, young lady. And that thing, as you so arrogantly put it, is part of the most advanced entity in the cosmos. Certainly more advanced than a mere human like you.
MEL: Or indeed you.
LOOZLY: That is to my eternal regret. Come, Gholos. Our apologies for this misunderstanding.
MEL: He sounds pretty steamed up.
LOOZLY: To be blunt, he is outraged at your slanders. He wants me to write a sternly worded letter complaining about your conduct.
NICKY: Mel? Oh, hello, Mel.
LOOZLY: Excuse us.
NICKY: Hey, watch it, Mister Loozly.
NICKY: What’s he so steamed up about? You all right, Mel? Thought I could hear you, finished my interview. Thought we could have our chat, go for a swim? What’s going on? You look a bit shaken up.
MEL: Nicky, that creature, it tried to kill me.
ELEANOR: But Ivor, what actually befell the Commander’s shuttle?
IVOR: I just don’t know, Eleanor. Perhaps some freak effect. Magnetic space lightning, cloud of invisible particles. Or some kind of new alien energy that just doesn’t show up on our scanners. I just don’t know.
ELEANOR: Commander, you look troubled.
DOCTOR: I’m fine, really.
ELEANOR: The object you lost, it was of sentimental value?
DOCTOR: Irreplaceable.
ELEANOR: I'm sorry. If you ever need to talk, the door to my quarters is always open, John.
DOCTOR: Er, oh, thank you.
ELEANOR: I was able to be of great personal comfort to Commander Keel.
DOCTOR: Oh, yes, I'll bear that in mind.
STRINDBERG: Commander?
DOCTOR: What is it, Lieutenant Strindberg?
STRINDBERG: I’m picking up alarming reports on the space news channels.
DOCTOR: Oh, switch it on. I mean, patch them through.
STRINDBERG: Aye, sir.
REPORTER: [OC]: Terrorist ships have broken through the security cordon, the so-called ring of iron around Achilles Four, and all fortified SSTs. The Achilles Four interceptors engaged with the first wave with limited success, but now the second wave of fighters have struck from delta sector.
ANCHORMAN: [OC]: And what can you see from where you're standing, Brian?
REPORTER: [OC]: It’s just
ELEANOR: Achilles Four is under attack.
DOCTOR: I think we’ve heard enough, Lieutenant.
IVOR: This is terrible. That station was brand new. It was supposed to be impregnable.
DOCTOR: Nothing’s impregnable if you have the right equipment. Or the right information.
ELEANOR: This was the last best hope for peace between Gholos and Angvia.
DOCTOR: Yes, if the Achilles Four conference fails, war rages on forever.
ELEANOR: If only we could do something. Oh, I feel so helpless.
DOCTOR: We can do something.
IVOR: What?
DOCTOR: Our bit. We keep our peckers up, we put our shoulders to the wheel, our noses to the grindstone, our backs to the trough and our elbows in the grease, to make sure this Intergalactic Song Contest is the best the universe has ever seen, or will ever see. We show the warmakers that music can bring harmony.
MEL: Let’s do the show right here, in the barn.
DOCTOR: Don't be so cynical, Mel.
LOGAN: And it appears Achilles Four has been attacked by Angvian separatists. Oh dear. You have to ask yourself, what’s going through the minds of these people? Well, I suppose it’s back to the contest. Something to cheer us all up. Or not. The arena’s just beginning to fill up. Let me just describe the arena to you. The seating holds forty thousand specially invited audience members. What an honour to be invited, eh? And there they are, enjoying the hospitality, staggering back to their seats. There are two hundred thousand mini- crystal hovercams covering every angle of the performance space, beaming every detail of each song to a quinquillion homes across the universe. Ah yes, you can bet it’s going to be an unforgettable night.
MEL: What do you mean, they can’t find the Tardis?
DOCTOR: It’s not showing up on their scans, so the Professor says.
MEL: Perhaps it’s floated off somewhere.
DOCTOR: Impossible.
MEL: Or it really did get blown up.
DOCTOR: Equally impossible. The Tardis is impregnable. Oh.
MEL: What?
DOCTOR: Nothing. But the Tardis is indestructible, ergo, it must be out there.
MEL: Ergo their scanners are playing up. Or
DOCTOR: Ergo?
MEL: The Professor is lying. You know, I thought there was something odd about him.
DOCTOR: There’s something odd about plenty of people. It doesn’t make them liars. But it certainly adds to the mystery.
MEL: And I’ve got yet another piece of that jigsaw.
DOCTOR: Yes?
MEL: Gholos attacked me in Cyrene’s room. Loozly called it off, and it said it was just looking for clues same as me, but it was glowing bright red and looked furious.
DOCTOR: Oh, Mel, are you all right?
MEL: Ah, you know me, Doctor. Takes more than a stroppy alien to shake me up. How would I cope with you otherwise? I reckon Professor Fassbinder and Gholos are in this together. He blew up the shuttle, and Gholos killed Cyrene, and tried to kill me to cover up the evidence.
DOCTOR: Brilliant.
MEL: What?
DOCTOR: An astonishing display.
MEL: Really?
DOCTOR: Of leaping to hasty conclusions. You’ve no evidence to support your theory.
MEL: I suppose not. But have you got any evidence to disprove it?
DOCTOR: Not yet. I suggest we keep our eyes peeled, our ears pricked and our other sensory appendages primed.
MEL: I have been.
DOCTOR: Really? Oh, you’ve already missed something important.
MEL: What?
DOCTOR: When we discovered Cyrene
MEL: What?
DOCTOR: Ah.
MEL: Oh no, Doctor, spill the beans.
DOCTOR: Unlike you, Mel, I won’t spill my beans until I Know how many of them make five.
MEL: Eh?
DOCTOR: Come in!
STRINDBERG: Excuse me, Commander. Sorry to disturb you in your ready room, but your presence is requested in the contestant’s lounge. There’s some kind of disturbance.
MEL: No prizes for guessing who that it.
ANGVIA: Those terrorists are not affiliated to the Angvian State. They have no connection with the Angvian State. They do not represent the species of the Angvian State.
LOOZLY: This is a deliberate attempt to destroy the peace process, to besmirch the good name of Gholos by provoking a walk-out by the Gholos delegation. A flagrant breach of trust by the Angvian delegation.
GERI: Stop, stop, just stop it! This contest is designed to create an atmosphere of harmony between all races. It is not political.
LOOZLY: At this time, every act is a political act.
GERI: These people are terrorists. They want to provoke war and aggression between us. If we argue we will be giving them exactly what they want. We must strive to rise above their provocation.
DOCTOR: I couldn’t have put it better myself.
NICKY: Hi, Mel. That’s the Commander?
DOCTOR: And you must be Nicky Newman?
NICKY: You don’t know me either? Oh, fantastic.
DOCTOR: Now, Mister Loozly. Melanie has explained what happened just now.
MEL: Gholos attacked me, that’s what.
LOOZLY: He did no such thing.
DOCTOR: And we are happy to accept your apologies.
ANGVIA: I am not
DOCTOR: We are all happy to accept your apologies!
NICKY: I wish it would stop fizzing like that. It’s making me feel ill.
LOOZLY: Gholos is naturally anxious. First the murder of Cyrene, now the attack on Achilles Four. The contest should be called off.
GERI: That is out of the question. Please, try to remain calm.
DOCTOR: Yes. It’s time for everyone to stop getting so red in the face. Including you, Gholos.
LOOZLY: Gholos only turns this colour in a time of extreme crisis.
DOCTOR: Crisis? What crisis? Please, Gholos, you are safe. And while I command Dark Space Eight, you will come to no harm. I’m going to assign er security patrols to all area, and I'll put the station on full alert. But
DOCTOR: the contest is most definitely going ahead. Ah, Eleanor.
ELEANOR: Commander. I’ve got the results of the tests on Cyrene’s body.
ANGVIA: Now we will know the truth, the blue sting of Gholos.
ELEANOR: The results are inconclusive. Cyrene died from a massive internal haemorrhage, a sudden and tremendous shock to the neuro-cortex the brain.
ANGVIA: Let me see those scans.
ELEANOR: It’s impossible to tell what caused that shock.
LOOZLY: What about the marks on the skin?
ELEANOR: There’s no way of telling what could have the scarring on the tissue, or whether it’s even connected to the neural spasm.
MEL: Right. So everybody can just calm down and focus on the contest.
GERI: Hear, hear.
LOOZLY: This is typical human behaviour, burying your heads in the sand. Come, Gholos. (leaves)
ANGVIA: You do well, Commander. Very well. Now, I trust you will respect the customs of my people and, before the contest, you will dine with me.
DOCTOR: Er, naturally.
ANGVIA: Good. I will see you in the dining sphere at 1800 hours.
DOCTOR: It will be a pleasure.
ANGVIA: I’m sure it will. (leaves)
NICKY: Phew. I don’t envy you, Commander.
GERI: It is an Angvian tradition to take a meal with the chief of the village they are visiting. I hope you don’t mind, Commander?
DOCTOR: Not at all. I’m feeling rather peckish. Now then. Ah. Oh, isn’t it quiet all of a sudden. Perhaps it’s a good time for us all to have a rest.
NICKY: Come on in, Mel, the water’s lovely.
MEL: It’s freezing!
NICKY: Yeah, I was lying. The heating must have packed up like everything else on this station.
MEL: The way the Professor and Eleanor talk, you’d think the place was a hot-bed of adventure.
NICKY: Once, maybe. I mean, my mum was really made up that I was coming to Dark Space Eight, because it used to be in the news all the time. You know, invasions foiled, all that bit. Look, are you coming in or not?
MEL: Okay, okay, here goes. (splash) Ah! It’s even colder in here than I
NICKY: Don’t be such a baby.
MEL: (shivering) Oh, don’t worry about me. I seem to spend my whole life being wet and cold. Er, being a pilot, I mean.
NICKY: Right. So how did you get into that, then?
MEL: Oh, you know, the usual way. I mean, it’s nowhere near as exciting as what you do.
NICKY: Don’t you believe it. Everybody thinks that. All I ever get is, aren’t you lucky. Well, when they can actually manage to speak to me instead of just staring and dribbling.
MEL: That’s the price of fame, I suppose.
NICKY: Yeah. But everybody thinks they know me, and everybody has an opinion about me. Can you imagine what that’s like? I haven’t even met most of them. But even when I do, people think I’ve said too much, or I haven’t said enough, or I’m being over-friendly, or not friendly enough, or that I’m too aloof, or that I’m trying too hard to be down to earth. Honestly, Mel, it drives me mad. I was sitting on that shuttle here, all the flight crew muttering about me, screaming fans floating over my shoulder, feeling like death, my head thumping.
MEL: Well, I suppose you
NICKY: It was only that Mister Loozly who was polite enough to ask me how I was. And that’s only because he’s been living in candyfloss land for years. I had to cadge a headache pill off him because I couldn’t face another round of giggling from the stewardess. And I mean, have you any idea how sick I feel right now, knowing I’ve got to go on in front of God knows how many billion people and sing? Don’t get me started on how the media portray me, because. Oh God. Look, I’m sorry. Listen to me. Poor little rich boy.
MEL: So why don’t you give it up? You could walk away, couldn’t you? Go home.
NICKY: Are you mad? My manager would kill me. And my mum. And as for the fans.
MEL: But you can’t live your life for other people.
TANNOY: Would Mister White please come to the media-sphere. (repeats under)
NICKY: Oh God, not again.
MEL: Hmm?
NICKY: Mister White. That’s me. It’s what they call me so that people won't follow me about, or send a paparazzi-cam after me. Must be another fan club chat or something. Christ, I’m sick of this.
MEL: Well, take my advice then, and
NICKY: You just don’t get it, do you? Don’t even try to understand cos you can't. I’ve got to go. Laters.
MEL: Hey, I was only trying to help. What’s got into him?
LOGAN: Well, the band’s tuning up, the guests are supping up, and the acts are giving up. Any ideas of doing a runner, that is. As for me, well, I’m keeping meself busy whilst we wait for tonight’s festivities to kick off. Now, I get a lot of letters, surprising though that may seem, and some of them even ask me sensible questions. Some of the ones I can read, that is. Ha, ha.
