Now, some of you have been wondering how I can comment on the songs when I can’t even say the names of half of them. Good question, there. Well, this year I’ve got something to beat my critics with, and it isn’t a stick this time.
LOGAN: [OC]: No, old Logan isn’t quite as stupid as he seems, as I’ve been working on me own little translator unit for the last couple of months. And if the lure of the hospitality bar isn’t too great, I’m hoping to have it ready in time for the contest. That way, I can give ‘em all a fair chance before I stamp all over them. (laughs) Anyways, I'll hand you over now to Burt Swanley and the Debonaires, who thought they might inflict a little bit of real music on you all before we get down to business. This is Logan singing off for now.
MEL: Hello? Oh, Mister Loozly. Is your er friend not about?
LOOZLY: Gholos is not my friend. Don’t be ridiculous. He’s resting in his cabin. With this device, he can summon me when required, and I can monitor his vital signs. Life away from the gestalt is trying for him. Satisfied?
MEL: Right. Good. I’ve just had a swim. It’s good for the heart, you know. Especially in water that cold.
LOOZLY: How fascinating.
MEL: Don’t they have swimming pools on Gholos’s planet?
LOOZLY: The world of Gholos is in many ways, I am sure, beyond your comprehension, young lady.
MEL: I’ve been to a lot of strange places.
LOOZLY: You talk a lot too.
MEL: It’s called being sociable.
LOOZLY: Oh, forgive me. I’m not used to other humans.
DOCTOR: I think you'll find they’re called people.
MEL: Hello, Commander.
DOCTOR: You must have some human friends, Mister Loozly?
LOOZLY: I worked in Earth Security for several years. I still keep in touch with some of the people there, I suppose. That’s how I first came to visit Gholos, on a diplomatic mission some oh, twenty years ago now.
DOCTOR: I hear it’s a bit misty.
LOOZLY: Misty?
DOCTOR: Yes.
LOOZLY: Gholos is oneness, a myriad of shifting colours, some you wouldn't even recognise. The stream of thought that surrounds the gestalt is serene, beautiful. Beings of pure mental energy, creatures of thought, souls, you might say. Can you imagine what that feels like? Not to have to drag this carcase with its needs, its hunger, its incessant demands around with you.
MEL: I quite like my carcase, actually
LOOZLY: (laughs) I didn’t really think you’d understand, but, Melanie, I really am happy there.
DOCTOR: As long as you’re happy, Mister Loozly. Mel, we must get back to the Command Deck, and keep an eye on that space battle.
MEL: I'll be up in a minute.
MEL: So, tell me more about what you do when you're with the gestalt.
LOOZLY: Well, if you’re really interested about the er
ANCHORMAN: [OC]: We've been hearing rumours all afternoon, Brian, so is there anything you can tell us at this stage?
REPORTER: [OC]: Er, well, there has been no official statement as yet, but just a few moments ago I saw the last of the terrorist ships make hyperjump, with the fleet in hot pursuit. So, as far as any of us can tell, the attack on Achilles Four is now ovet..
ANCHORMAN: [OC]: So the conference seems to be safe.
REPORTER: [OC]: That’s certainly the feeling here, Michael, and given the casualties the attackers suffered, I think it’s safe to say that a second attack is unlikely
ANCHORMAN: [OC]: There’s been a lot said here about the pincer attack the terrorist ships adopted. Can you tell us any more about that?
REPORTER: [OC]: Er, well, er, certainly from where I was sitting their tactics seemed very weak
DOCTOR: I think weak might be something of an understatement.
STRINDBERG: Commander?
DOCTOR: Hmm? Oh, nothing, Lieutenant. Nothing. Just talking to myself. Terrible habit of mine. Anyway, it
DOCTOR: looks like the Peace Conference had a lucky escape.
STRINDBERG: It’s lucky for us all.
DOCTOR: Indeed, indeed. I wonder if you might do me a favour, Lieutenant, and pop across the way to tell Eleanor. I know how worried she is.
STRINDBERG: Of course, sir. Right away.
MEL: Oh, sorry.
STRINDBERG: After you, Miss. Please excuse me.
DOCTOR: Ah, Pilot Mel. Been having fun?
MEL: I actually had quite a nice chat with our Mister LoozZly.
DOCTOR: Really?
MEL: Mmm. He isn't half as fierce away from that Gholos thing. I just don’t think he’s very good with humans.
DOCTOR: (laughs) And I’ve no doubt he received the full Melanie Bush course in people skills.
MEL: Gratis and for nothing. So what have you been up to whilst oh. What was that?
DOCTOR: Over there, under the door. It’s a note.
MEL: Nobody around. Hello? Who's there? Hello?
DOCTOR: Curiouser and curiouser.
MEL: What’s it say?
DOCTOR: Commander. Beware the pits of Angvia.
MEL: No name?
DOCTOR: Nothing.
MEL: The pits of Angvia? What’s that supposed to mean?
DOCTOR: Pits? I don’t remember there being any pits on Angvia. Very big trees, as I recall, but no pits. And anyway, the planet’s halfway across space from here.
MEL: Or maybe it’s meant to throw us. You know, send us off on a wild goose chase.
DOCTOR: But it’s meaningless. I mean, if you wanted to befuddle someone, you’d make up something more cryptic, less specific.
MEL: Well, whoever left it obviously wants to implicate our friendly neighbourhood Valkyrie in this mess. I mean, it could have been Lieutenant Strindberg. He was close by, and he
DOCTOR: Oh, Mel.
MEL: Sorry. But someone left it. Hey. Perhaps it was the Professor. I mean, we don’t know what sort of devices he could have hidden in here. Maybe he heard us talking earlier and decided to shift the blame.
DOCTOR: Maybe, maybe not. Maybe it was Eleanor, or Loozly, or Nicky, or Geri, or old Mister Jenkins the Janitor. I could go on all afternoon and it still wouldn’t get us anywhere. The only people we can rule out are you and me. Unless there’s something you're not telling me?
MEL: Oh, very funny. Well, I still think it’s a good theory. And I’m going to go have a nose round the Professor’s lab. If nothing else, it might mean we can cross off a suspect.
DOCTOR: Professor Fassbinder, with the lead piping in the lab. Oh, all right then. But be careful.
MEL: I’m not the one who needs to be careful. You’ve got a date with Angvia.
ELEANOR: There you are, Mister Newman. These drugs should help with your headache and nausea.
NICKY: I don’t like the look of them. What are they?
ELEANOR: They're an extract of Malvolian fungoid.
NICKY: Wish I hadn’t asked.
ELEANOR: Have you taken any other drugs in the last twenty four hours?
NICKY: I had an aspirin on the shuttle.
ELEANOR: Well, these shouldn't react adversely with that.
NICKY: They smell funny. Mel? Hey, Mel?
MEL: Oh, it’s you. What do you want? I’m busy.
NICKY: Look, I’m sorry we had that little row, or spat, or whatever it was.
MEL: I wasn’t aware that we’d had a row. As I recall, I was trying to be helpful and you were shouting at me.
NICKY: Oh. Yeah. Sorry. Friends?
MEL: Yes, okay. I could do with some help.
ELEANOR: Oh, really? With what, exactly?
MEL: Oh, never mind. It’s nothing important. Come on, Nicky.
NICKY: Yeah, coming. Thanks for the pills, Doc.
ELEANOR: What? Oh, yes, yes. Mmm.
DOCTOR: Yes, if I could just squeeze past?
ANGVIA: Ah, Commander. I was beginning to fear you were not coming.
DOCTOR: Oh, I never break a date.
ANGVIA: And I have never been, how do you say on Earth, stood down? Do you wish to see the menu?
DOCTOR: Oh, thank you.
ROBOT WAITER: Good evening, sir, madam. May I take your order?
DOCTOR: Oh yes. Yes, I'll have a Pamperanian fritters to start with.
ANGVIA: I will not have a starter. We of Angvia do not have starters. I’m interested only in the main course.
DOCTOR: Oh. In which case then
ANGVIA: Rump of Argelian Starbison, rare.
DOCTOR: Er, twice, please.
ROBOT WAITER: Very good, sir, madam.
DOCTOR: Well, er
ANGVIA: Well.
DOCTOR: Well, here we are.
ANGVIA: Yes. We are here.
DOCTOR: Here we are, then.
ANGVIA: Yes.
DOCTOR: We’re agreed on that, anyway. My old philosopher friend Descartes could never decide if he was here or not. Played havoc when it came to working out the bill.
ANGVIA: (laughs hysterically) Oh, Commander. Oh, you are so, so witty! My, but it’s warm in here. I’ll just remove my helmet.
DOCTOR: Ooo, your hair.
ANGVIA: What of it?
DOCTOR: Well, it’s very lovely. I mean, it’s very long.
ANGVIA: Do Earth women also have lovely hair?
DOCTOR: Er, yes, yes, I suppose so. I’ve never really thought about it. Strange. So, your people have been at war with Gholos for a very long time. How did it all get started, anyway? I’m rather vague on the details.
ANGVIA: It’s all ancient history. It does not matter tonight.
DOCTOR: All these border incursions seem to be
ANGVIA: Politics. Ah, no, it is a bore. I know little of such matters. We learn the worst of the crimes by rote at the seminar, but I was always an entertainer in my heart and soul.
DOCTOR: Yes. Er, nice view.
ANGVIA: The wall?
DOCTOR: Well, it’s quite a nice wall.
ANGVIA: No, it is not.
DOCTOR: I don’t suppose it is.
ANGVIA: Forgive me, Commander. I must be blunt with you.
DOCTOR: Be as blunt as you like.
ANGVIA: Ever since we met, I have felt something inside me, stirring.
DOCTOR: You should go to the sickbay.
ANGVIA: Sickbay? Ha. Doctors cannot cure love.
DOCTOR: Love?
ANGVIA: You act as if you’ve never heard the word before.
DOCTOR: Well, I’ve heard of it, but perhaps you’re having a bit of a difficulty with our language.
ANGVIA: No. I said love. I mean love.
DOCTOR: Er, what sort of love do you mean? Professional admiration? Platonic affection? Quite liking someone in a distant abstract sort of way?
ANGVIA: I am talking of mad passionate love! Embraces under the stars. On Angvia we women choose our mates.
DOCTOR: Sort of like a ladies’ excuse-me kind of thing.
ANGVIA: I know nothing of this ladies’ excuse-me. All I know is what my heart tells me. I look into your eyes and I see boiling masculine virility under the flimsy lid of your beauty.
DOCTOR: Do you?
ANGVIA: Come here!
DOCTOR: Argh!
ANGVIA: Rest your head on my bosom. You hear my heart pounding?
DOCTOR: (muffled) Mmph.
ANGVIA: Feel it?
DOCTOR: (muffled) Yes. It’s actually rather comfortable.
ANGVIA: Now, do you feel love?
DOCTOR: What? I. Yes. Yes, strangely enough, I think I’m beginning to
NICKY: So why are we looking for the Professor?
MEL: Shh. We’re not. We’re just going for a little nose round his lab.
NICKY: But, won't he mind?
MEL: If we’re careful, he’ll never know. Professor? Professor Fassbinder, are you there? Great. It’s lucky he never seems to be around. Come on, and be careful.
NICKY: We shouldn’t be doing this, Mel. The tabloids’ll have a field day if I get wrapped up in, well, I don’t know, breaking and entering or whatever it is we’re doing.
MEL: All the more reason to shut up and start looking around.
NICKY: What for?
MEL: I don’t know. Clues. Anything suspicious. This is a murder investigation, remember. Look for something murderous.
NICKY: All right, all right. (beeps) Whoa!
MEL: Shh!
NICKY: Sorry. What was that?
MEL: Hmm?
NICKY: Someone’s coming.
MEL: What? You’re right. Quick, behind this thing.
NICKY: Who is it? Can you see?
MEL: I don’t recognise him.
NICKY: Let me see. It’s Logan, the commentator. He interviewed me once.
MEL: You don’t suppose he’s mixed up in all this?
NICKY: Him? No, he can’t be.
LOGAN: Who’s there? Who, who, who
MEL: He’s found us. I’d better come clean. (normal) Mister Logan? Er, hello. My name’s Mel. I’m here with Nicky Newman.
NICKY: Hi.
MEL: We were just waiting for Professor Fassbinder to come back and er
MEL: Are you all right? What’s wrong?
NICKY: Oh no. Oh no, is that
MEL: Oh, Mister Logan? Mister Logan?
LOGAN: This is Logan, signing off.
MEL: Nicky, at the risk of making a habit out of this kind of thing, he’s dead. He’s been stabbed in the back!

elements.text: [Part Three]
You are a very beautiful woman.
And you, Commander, are such a handsome man. The way your hair curls under your hat, those deep grey eyes, so mysterious.

It’s been a very, very long time since I felt anything like this, and so strongly. Oh, Angvia, how could I have been so blind. Wherever we go in the universe, one thing is constant. Hoards of hairy aliens descend in their battle cruisers, men in plastic overalls hurry down corridors, the red shift gobbles up planets at the edge of Time, but in all those places, love is real.
Oh, Commander, kiss me!
Love. Oh Angvia, what have I been doing all these centuries? I’ve wasted so much time fighting monsters when I should have been tasting life’s great sweetener, amour.
Yes, all right, I get where you’re coming from. Now, kiss me!
[OC]: Commander Ballard, please report urgently to Command deck.
No, no, not now, not now.
Don’t answer, Commander, my love.
[OC]: Please report urgently to Command deck.
Yes, I'll ignore it.
Fall into my arms.
[OC]: Commander Ballard, please report urgently to Command deck.
No, don’t listen to it. Tonight Dark Space Eight can look after itself. This night was made for love
I, I can’t. Angvia, I must go. The universe can’t be trusted to itself.
The universe can wait. Iam a woman!
I’m sorry, my love, but it will only be for a short while, until I’ve solved this invasion or power-mad scheme or whatever it is today.
Then hurry. You have lit the flame and only you can put it out.
I will return soon.
Oh, my little man.

Dark Space Eight status report, day 4,816 of operation. Chief Medic Eleanor Harcourt reporting. The unexpected death of the Earth commentator Logan has created an unsettling atmosphere aboard the station, and has even cast doubt on the continuation of the Intergalactic Song Contest. We can only hope that the results of my post mortem examination will quell the tide of rising anxiety which threatens to engulf our normally happy community. On a more personal note, my concern is also growing for the welfare of Commander Ballard, whose behaviour seems to become ever stranger as his acquaintance with Queen Angvia grows more familiar. It pains me to say that I can foresee the day when it may be my duty to rescue the Commander from the unwanted attentions of that, that Queen Angvia. In the meantime, I must report to sickbay to examine the body of the unfortunate commentator, Logan. Harcourt out.
But who could have wanted to kill the commentator? And where’s Professor Fassbinder? What’s going on in Dark Space Eight, Doc, er Commander. Commander?
(dreamily) Huh? Oh, sorry, Mel. I was just, er, pondering the mystery.
Surely now you’re going to stop the contest.
Well, it is an option, I suppose.
Commander? Are you all right?
Oh, I’m fine. Fine.
Well, come on, then.
Come on where?
What do you think?
The contest is imminent, Commander.
All the more reason to cancel it.
Mel’s right. We can’t go on.
Your stage fright’s by the by. We can’t ignore another murder.
Do you think that’s why I want the contest pulled? You must think a lot of me.
Door opens and closes.
Ah, Commander.
Oh dear, every time that door opens I pray it’s not going to be him.
I’ve heard about the murder.
Ah, I suppose you want the contest cancelled.
Certainly not.
Really, Mister Loozly? You surprise me.
I have no opinion of my own. I merely relay Gholos’s thoughts.
So all that crackling means the opposite of what it said before? Sounds just the same to me.

Gholos considers that it is now far too late to cancel the contest. The eyes of billions of beings across the universe are trained here, on Dark Space Eight. The evening’s presentation has already begun. To pull out this late would give the murderer, whoever it may be, exactly what she wants.
By she, I presume you mean Angvia?
Impossible. I was with Queen Angvia when Logan was murdered.
Oh, really. How very convenient. The perfect alibi.
Door opens and closes.
John, I’ve examined the body of the commentator.
Oh. And?
Come on, Commander. Show some interest.
He was stabbed.
I could have told you that.
There were no fingerprints on the vibro-knife.
Did you carry out a psycho-genetic test?
Of course, Ambassador. The results were
Don't tell me. Negative.
Great. Come on, Commander, the final decision’s up to you. We've got just under an hour till the contest begins. Are you going to cancel it?
Well, no. No, no, on reflection
Excellent. A wise choice, Commander. I shall tell the team in the concert hall to proceed as planned. Mister Loozly, Gholos, Mister Newman, I suggest you prepare for your performances.
Indeed. Come, Gholos.
I just don’t think I can do it, Mel. My stomach’s getting worse.
Get Doctor Harcourt to check you out.
No ta. She gave me these horrible pills last time. Anyway, doctor’s scare me.
Is there anything that doesn’t? Go back to your cabin and try to get some rest before you go on. I'll see you later.
Okay. Thanks for the sympathy.
If you want a normal friendship, you’d better learn the rules.
Door opens and closes.
That was rather harsh, Mel.
You haven't seen the half of it. Where can we talk privately? Ah, Commander’s ready room. Come on, you.
Door opens.
Mel, whatever’s the matter?
You tell me.
Door closes.
What’s wrong with you?
Nothing.
I’ve never seen you like this before. You seem distracted, like the murders don’t matter.
Of course they matter.
Out there you looked like you were drifting off, like your mind was somewhere else.
Did I?
You're doing it again.
Am I?
What’s got into you? I expect a certain amount of eccentricity, but never disinterest.
Oh Mel, now you come to mention it, I do feel a little strange.
Hold on. Did anything happen while you were with Angvia?
What do you mean by that?
I just wondered if she said or did anything that gave you pause for thought. Doctor, what’s wrong?
Mel, you know me, the things I always do, the things I never do.
Of course.
The things I always do?
Charge round the universe setting wrongs to right, generally.
And never?
Well, you’re never nasty or deliberately cruel.
And?
And you never. Well, you never. No!
For a horrible moment back there, Mel, yes. Or nearly.
With Angvia?
Yes.
I must say, after, well, after several hundred years of celibacy, that’s a pretty odd place to start up again.
There’s something wrong here, Mel. Something very wrong indeed. I’ve got to pull myself together There are lives at stake. Mind on the job and all that.
I think you ought to get your mind off the job. It sounds like you’ve been having some sort of mid- regeneration crisis. Oh, we'll sort that out later.
Er, yes, hmm. So. So what did the Professor say when you went to see him in the lab?
I was trying to tell you. He was nowhere to be found.
Oh, Mel!
I did have a man bleeding on me at the time.
Yes, and that’s another thing. I mean, what did our murderer have to gain by killing the commentator?
It seems pretty obvious. A high profile target. One of the most famous people here, according to Nicky.
On the surface, yes. I’m just trying to remember what he was (lightbulb) Ah yes. Yes.
Oh, come on, Doctor. Spit it out.
Apply your elephantine memory, Mel, and I’m sure you'll draw the same conclusions as this love- struck old fool.
Oh, you’re back to your old self, all right. The only conclusion I’ve drawn is that the Prof’s done a runner.
Well, see if you can find him, then.
So you do think he’s behind it. At last.
No comment.
Oh, I give up. Doctor, do you know what happened to Sherlock Holmes in the end?
What?
Watson bashed him over the head with his own violin for being so aggravating. I’m off to find the Professor.
Tapping microphone.
Is this on? Oh. Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. My name is Sven Strindberg, and I am

to be your commentator for this evening’s contest due to the er unavailability of your regularly scheduled host. Get well soon, Mister Logan. And as the hall fills with er people who want to er see this contest, here, this evening, in the er, hall. Oh dear.
Door’s open.
Door opens.
Ah. Eleanor.
John. I wondered if you needed anything.
Oh. No thank you. Just pondering.
Strange. Paul, Commander Keel, used to sit just there, gazing into the infinity of space.
Did it help him?
Oh yes. I remember when Dark Space Eight had been stricken with the Altairian plague. Everybody’s usual inhibitions went flying out the window. Every passionate thought, every repressed instinct
And how did he solve the problem?
He reversed the station’s air-conditioning system. After a while, anyway.
If only this problem could be solved so easily.
You're still no nearer to the solution, John?
Tell me, Doctor Harcourt. What do you think of Professor Fassbinder?
I trust Ivor with my life. We’ve been through so much together. I remember when a being called Zeon appeared out of space, freezing us all and claiming to be God
Yes, yes. But he’s a trustworthy character?
And a great scientist.
Knocking on door.
Oh, Commander. I see you are busy.
Oh, no, no, your Graciousness. Please come in.
Are you sure?
Shouldn’t you be getting ready for the contest, Queen Angvia?
Yes, of course. I just wanted a few words with the Commander.
I'll attend to my other duties, then.
Door closes.
She is very lonely woman, the doctor.
You think so?
There is some hidden sadness behind her eyes. I sense it. We of Angvia have sharp instincts. Just as my instincts told me that you, Commander, are a very passionate man.
Ah. Now, er, Queen Angvia, we really must have a chat about that, and you’re due on the stage very soon. Oh please, I’d rather you didn’t do that. Oh, now really.
We have time enough for love, Commander.
We really don't.
We have.
We haven't.
Come to me.
No. I must insist.
Are you telling me to leave?
No. Yes! Yes, yes, please. I’m telling you to leave.
No. The shame of it.
Well, nobody else knows about er you know, us.
(crying) That is not the point. I’m the fourteenth Queen of the house of Silsitor. To be rejected by a mere male is shame eternal.
Well, I’m just not like the other boys.
You're not like any other men. You are a great mystery. I go to sing. To sing away my tears.
Door opens and closes.
This is most peculiar. Why am I behaving like this? Come on, Doctor, think!
Mel to Commander. Come in, Commander. Oh, how does this thing work?
You press the middle bit.
Oh, Nicky. You scared me.
Sorry, Mel. Actually, I really am sorry. I’ve been acting like an idiot. I bought you this to say, well, sorry.
Oh Nicky, it’s lovely. I didn’t know roses grew in space.
No, there’s a gift shop on level th... oh, teasing me, yes?
‘Fraid so. It’s very sweet of you. Listen to me, Nicky Newman. You have to learn to loosen up a bit. You can't live your lift for a group of people you don’t even know. Look what it’s doing to you.
I know, I know. After this is over, I’ll sort something out. Promise. When it’s over. God, I can hardly
even bear to think of what I’ve
Don't, then. Come and help me. I’m trying to find Professor Fassbinder, and I’m not having much luck. With that or with this stupid communicator thing.
Have you tried in the main hall? Maybe he’s helping them out with, I don’t know, science things.
Hmm, that must be the only place I haven’t tried. Come on.
General hubbub of voices.
[OC]: So, yes, not long to go now. Ah, even less time now. (laughs) Oh.
I’d rather not go in.
Afraid of being recognised? Just put a bag on your head.
Okay, sorry. I’m being unreasonable again, aren’t I?
Asmidge. It’s dark back here. Nobody’s going to... Nicky, over there.
Where? What?
Right at the back of the auditorium. Surely that’s
The Professor.
The elusive Professor. At last. Now we'll get to the truth.
Professor Fassbinder, I know everything. The game’s up. It’s time for you to confess.
Mel.
You’ve been trying to stop the contest for some reason, and you deliberately falsified the test on our shuttle, and you killed the commentator.
Mel, I think he’s dead.
I oh er ring of satellites. Ring of satellites.
No, he isn’t. But we’ve got to get him to Doctor Harcourt, and fast.
Young lady, there is no question of Professor Fassbinder neglecting his duties.
Look at him. He must have been taking something.
The hassle of the contest must have got to him. You see a lot of it in this business.
More likely he’s been trying to assuage the guilt, to wash away the stain of murder.
Now, now, Mel. Thank you for calling me, Eleanor. Now what exactly is wrong with the Professor?
John, I just don’t know. I'll have to carry out a full range of tests.
Wait a moment. Professor? Listen. It’s the Commander.
Somebody. Somebody had
Somebody had the er what?
It’s the
He’s pointing to his throat.
Let’s see. Loosen his collar.
Oh no.
John, what is it?
You’re the doctor.
That mark on his neck, is it poison?
Almost certainly.
So I was wrong. Far from being the murderer, he’s victim number five. Er, three.
There may still be a chance.
I don’t think so, Eleanor. I’m sorry.
Oh, Ivor, try to tell us what happened? Who did this to you?
Someone must have heard the
Heard what?
lvor, remember when you and I and Commander Keel were accidentally transported back through Time and space to mediaeval Wales? You didn’t give up then, and you mustn't give up now.
Sorry, Eleanor. Oh, Eleanor, I wish I could have told you and Paul the truth.
I don’t understand.
I think I do. Professor, I know your secret.
He is the murderer.
Hush, Mel.
Sorry.
Tell them, Professor.
Don’t call me that.
What? I don’t understand.

Oh, Eleanor, all these years, whenever you or Paul asked me what’s that, or how do we get through this black hole, or whatever, I just used to say the first thing that came into my head. A cloud of neutrino charged ions, or we must invert the stations gravitic stabilisers, or stick a ring of satellites around the moon. It was all rubbish.
But, but why?
Because I was drunk. I was. I was drunk. I’ve barely been sober in twenty years. I can’t, I can’t remember the first thing about space science. Oh, Eleanor.
Oh, Ivor. Was it after your wife was killed by the sweat vampire? Is that why you turned to alcohol?
Good God, no. No, it was those loans. The loans started it. We’d re-mortgaged, you know.
Fascinating though this is
Who’s the murderer? That’s what we want to know.
Well, obviously. I’m quite surprised none of you have realised. I mean, quite plainly. Well, without any doubt in my mind, the murderer is urgh ack.
Quick! Revive him!
Too late, I’m afraid.
lvor? Gone, and there was nothing I could do. I feel so helpless.
What has been... oh! The Professor!
Right. The time has come for action.
You’re going to cancel the contest?
No. I’m putting Dark Space Eight into battlestations. Quarantine restrictions in full force. All subspace communications are suspended as from now. All security guards are to be armed with phasers.
Lasers.

Lasers, set to stun. Patrols to be increased. The Concert hall is to be isolated immediately and entry permitted only to grade one operatives. Say nothing to the guests. We don’t want a full-scale panic. Set to it, Ambassador.
Immediately, Commander.
Eleanor, I want a full run of tests on the poor Professor. Nicky, back to the Concert hall. And Mel, we’re going to have one of our little chats in the reading room.
The ready room.
Oh, the ready room.
So, this means the Tardis is out there after all.
Door closes.
The late Professor simply couldn’t work the machines properly.
Drunk in charge of a particle scanner. Tut, tut, tut, tut.
Well, it means we could just leave them to their squabbling and clear off.
I’m not sure whether to dignify that with an answer.
Just checking. Still, it means that we were wrong about the Professor.
We?
All right, I was wrong. His sneaking off was just so he could have a sly drink. Oh, I’ve drawn a blank. What about you, Doctor?

Hmm. I’ve got a couple of ideas. Look, Mel, could you go and keep an eye on things in the Concert hall, whilst I have a bit of a ponder? Our friend, whoever he or she may be, is here because of the contest. So, that’s where we need to concentrate our investigations.
Fobbed off again. Okay. But when I get back, I want to hear all about your oh-so-secret theories.
Door opens and closes.
I’m just hoping you don’t meet one of them face to face.

The Concert hall is filling up, the orchestra are tuning up. It’s certainly going to be good fun. Yes, in just fifteen minutes the Intergalactic Song Contest will begin. (mutters something) still fifteen minutes to go.
Yes, if there was a way of um. But only if he’d overheard the. But that would mean
Door opens.
Ah, Gholos.
Fizzing.
Oh, forgive me. I’m having a little difficulty understanding you. Without your friend, that is.
Commander.
Gholos seems to be rather agitated.

Gholos is desperate to reveal to you he has worked it all out. Angvia arranged the dinner with you to avoid being suspected of the Professor’s murder, which was committed with a slow-acting Angvian poison.
Was it?
I have checked in the sickbay.
Really?
You must arrest Angvia.
You’re sure your friend doesn’t have any more information? He seems a little over-excited.
Merely desperate that you should act immediately on his intelligence.
Oh. Thank you. Both. I'll certainly look into it. Now, if you’ll excuse me.
Very well. But heed our warning, Commander. Come, Gholos.
Aren’t you going with him?
Fizz. Door closes.
[OC]: Commander. Arbiter to Commander. Come in. Urgent.
This is no place for a good ponder. Commander here.
[OC]: Commander, I have grave news. It is Queen Angvia. She has been attacked in her own dressing room. Battered on the head.
Oh no! She isn’t
[OC]: No, thank the stars. She must have fought back, scared off the murderer.
Call Eleanor. Get Angvia to the sickbay.
[OC]: What shall I do?
You, stay exactly where you are. Commander out.
Commander, I’ve tried everything, but her lifesigns are very weak.
Let me see.
Angvian physiognomy is very different to ours.

Bottom. But only because of that outbreak of Scolostocks fever. I felt so

John!

Geri squealing and running.

Nicky, I’ve got it.

Who knows? But it fits all the facts. All three murders could be blamed on Angvia. Now she gets attacked herself, the implication will be that Gholos was the murderer, posing as her.

I’m a complicated kind of girl. Come on, let’s follow her, see what she’s up to.

Geri! Come on.
Cheers. Drumroll, orchestra.
Ladies and gentlebeings. Welcome one and all to the 309" Intergalactic Song Contest!
Cheers, applause.
And your host for this evening, in a change to the regularly scheduled artiste, Lieutenant Sven Strindberg!
Desultory applause.

Hello, good evening, and welcome to Dark Space Eight on this beautiful starlit night, out here among the er, stars where the biggest er, stars are gathering for what promises to be a star-studded occasion. Oh God. Where’s the thing? Oh, that. And kicking us off is act one from the Argol Cluster, here is Bilionius Grufang with Argol’s entry, Don’t Push Your Tentacle Too Far.
Sounds like a rusty machine powering up.
There she goes.
Mel, this is silly. My tummy’s really playing up. I think I need the toilet again.
Tie a knot in it. This is important. Where’s she creeping off to now?
Looks like the kitchens.
Very suspicious. Come on.
Angvia groans.
She’s coming round. Well done, John.
It was quite literally nothing. An, Queen Angvia. You’re quite safe. Can you tell us who attacked you?
But the implications of the territorial incursions by Gholos into our space in 61 Cygnii and the Questor Zone could not be ignored.
It sounds like it could be severe cranial trauma.
How very peculiar.
Noted, but I cannot comply. I suggest we move on to discuss resolution 5 para 2b, the question of a Court of Resolution.
It sounds political.
Angvia said she knew nothing about politics. Unless.
Right, she’s stopped. Keep quiet and I'll have a look-see.
Careful.
Discretion is my middle name. Nicky!
Shh.
Sorry, sorry. But what’s that she’s got?

Beeps.
Utiliser to Base. All is going according to plan despite the difficulties. Do you have further intelligence?
Ah! That's it. Proof positive.
Maybe she’s in with those terrorists.
It doesn’t matter. We've got to stop her.
She’s a fast mover, Mel.

Oh, God. Oh.
Carefully does it.
Understood. The most critical stage is almost

Struggle. Geri squeals, then a crunch.
Oh no, Geri! Geri!

She hit her head on the floor grating. She was struggling.
Do you know how delicate these things are?
No. I.
Oh God. Oh God. Mel, you’ve killed her! You’ve killed the Arbiter.
And the trade sanctions
What does this mean, John?
I don’t know. Or do I? Yes. Yes, of course. It all fits. Think about it.
[OC]: Commander.
Ah, Mel.
[OC]: I’m afraid something’s happened. You’d better get down here and, and Commander? Bring the doctor.
Get her onto the medi-sled. Quickly.
I didn’t know what I was doing.
Young lady, that is still to be determined. Quick, get her to sickbay.
Oh dear.
Listen, I was only doing what I thought was right.
I think we need one of our private little chats.
You're getting rid of me again.
You’re due on stage very soon.

(receding) Okay, okay.
Doctor, I’m sorry.
Sorry? Sorry? Mel, you’ve just attacked our greatest ally.
Hold on. You don’t know the half of it. Our ally was talking on a communicator about her plan.

What?
Haven't you worked it out? Didn’t you realise?
But I

Yes.

More important than any of us realise.
How?
Mel, all this talk of the Peace Conference on Achilles Four.
Yes?
There is no Peace Conference on Achilles Four. Whatever’s happening over there, it’s nothing but a side show. Dark Space Eight is what matters. This is the Peace Conference.

DOCTOR: You are a very beautiful woman.
ANGVIA: And you, Commander, are such a handsome man. The way your hair curls under your hat, those deep grey eyes, so mysterious.
DOCTOR: It’s been a very, very long time since I felt anything like this, and so strongly. Oh, Angvia, how could I have been so blind. Wherever we go in the universe, one thing is constant. Hoards of hairy aliens descend in their battle cruisers, men in plastic overalls hurry down corridors, the red shift gobbles up planets at the edge of Time, but in all those places, love is real.
ANGVIA: Oh, Commander, kiss me!
DOCTOR: Love. Oh Angvia, what have I been doing all these centuries? I’ve wasted so much time fighting monsters when I should have been tasting life’s great sweetener, amour.

ELEANOR: Dark Space Eight status report, day 4,816 of operation. Chief Medic Eleanor Harcourt reporting. The unexpected death of the Earth commentator Logan has created an unsettling atmosphere aboard the station, and has even cast doubt on the continuation of the Intergalactic Song Contest. We can only hope that the results of my post mortem examination will quell the tide of rising anxiety which threatens to engulf our normally happy community. On a more personal note, my concern is also growing for the welfare of Commander Ballard, whose behaviour seems to become ever stranger as his acquaintance with Queen Angvia grows more familiar. It pains me to say that I can foresee the day when it may be my duty to rescue the Commander from the unwanted attentions of that, that Queen Angvia. In the meantime, I must report to sickbay to examine the body of the unfortunate commentator, Logan. Harcourt out.

GERI: Queen Angvia, she’s been attacked.
MEL: What? Where is she?
GERI: The Commander sent guards to take her to sickbay.
NICKY: But is she okay?
GERI: I don’t know. Oh, but Commander told me to stay here and
MEL: Well then, do as he says and stay put.
GERI: But I’m the Arbiter. It’s my duty to do oh dear, I can’t stop to chat with you. I must get away.
NICKY: Mind out.
NICKY: Actually, I should have stayed put. Crushed by a flying fur ball so I didn’t have to sing.
MEL: Nicky, I’ve got it.
NICKY: What?
MEL: What better cover?
NICKY: What? Geri? But she’s a Pakhar, a pacifist. The Pakhars are the only creatures trusted with missions like this. They’re hosting the Peace Conference, for God’s sake.
MEL: A pacifist alien terrified of violence? The ideal smokescreen. What if Geri attacked Angvia and raised the alarm herself?
NICKY: Geri wanted the contest to go ahead, remember? That doesn’t square with what we know about the murderer.
MEL: Brilliant! That’s it! Geri wants the contest to go on, and blacken the name of Gholos throughout the galaxy.
NICKY: You've lost me. What’s Geri got against Gholos?
MEL: Who knows? But it fits all the facts. All three murders could be blamed on Angvia. Now she gets attacked herself, the implication will be that Gholos was the murderer, posing as her.
NICKY: Er, that’s a bit complicated.
MEL: I’m a complicated kind of girl. Come on, let’s follow her, see what she’s up to.
NICKY: Who, Angvia?
MEL: Geri! Come on.
ANNOUNCER: Ladies and gentlebeings. Welcome one and all to the 309" Intergalactic Song Contest!
ANNOUNCER: And your host for this evening, in a change to the regularly scheduled artiste, Lieutenant Sven Strindberg!
STRINDBERG: Hello, good evening, and welcome to Dark Space Eight on this beautiful starlit night, out here among the er, stars where the biggest er, stars are gathering for what promises to be a star-studded occasion. Oh God. Where’s the thing? Oh, that. And kicking us off is act one from the Argol Cluster, here is Bilionius Grufang with Argol’s entry, Don’t Push Your Tentacle Too Far.
MEL: There she goes.
NICKY: Mel, this is silly. My tummy’s really playing up. I think I need the toilet again.
MEL: Tie a knot in it. This is important. Where’s she creeping off to now?
NICKY: Looks like the kitchens.
MEL: Very suspicious. Come on.
ELEANOR: She’s coming round. Well done, John.
DOCTOR: It was quite literally nothing. An, Queen Angvia. You’re quite safe. Can you tell us who attacked you?
ANGVIA: But the implications of the territorial incursions by Gholos into our space in 61 Cygnii and the Questor Zone could not be ignored.
ELEANOR: It sounds like it could be severe cranial trauma.
DOCTOR: How very peculiar.
ANGVIA: Noted, but I cannot comply. I suggest we move on to discuss resolution 5 para 2b, the question of a Court of Resolution.
ELEANOR: It sounds political.
DOCTOR: Angvia said she knew nothing about politics. Unless.
MEL: Right, she’s stopped. Keep quiet and I'll have a look-see.
NICKY: Careful.
MEL: Discretion is my middle name. Nicky!
NICKY: Shh.
MEL: Sorry, sorry. But what’s that she’s got?
NICKY: Give us a look. It’s a subspace communicator.
MEL: But the Doc, Commander, banned them.
GERI: Utiliser to Base. All is going according to plan despite the difficulties. Do you have further intelligence?
MEL: Ah! That's it. Proof positive.
NICKY: Maybe she’s in with those terrorists.
MEL: It doesn’t matter. We've got to stop her.
NICKY: She’s a fast mover, Mel.
MEL: But we’ve got surprise on our side. I’m going to drag her away. Be ready to get her arms. She might have a gun.
NICKY: Oh, God. Oh.
MEL: Carefully does it.
GERI: Understood. The most critical stage is almost
MEL: Gotcha! Keep still!
MEL: Oh no, Geri! Geri!
NICKY: What have you done?
MEL: She hit her head on the floor grating. She was struggling.
NICKY: Do you know how delicate these things are?
MEL: No. I.
NICKY: Oh God. Oh God. Mel, you’ve killed her! You’ve killed the Arbiter.
ANGVIA: And the trade sanctions
ELEANOR: What does this mean, John?
DOCTOR: I don’t know. Or do I? Yes. Yes, of course. It all fits. Think about it.
MEL: [OC]: Commander.
DOCTOR: Ah, Mel.
MEL: [OC]: I’m afraid something’s happened. You’d better get down here and, and Commander? Bring the doctor.
ELEANOR: Get her onto the medi-sled. Quickly.
MEL: I didn’t know what I was doing.
ELEANOR: Young lady, that is still to be determined. Quick, get her to sickbay.
DOCTOR: Oh dear.
MEL: Listen, I was only doing what I thought was right.
DOCTOR: I think we need one of our private little chats.
NICKY: You're getting rid of me again.
DOCTOR: You’re due on stage very soon.
NICKY: We can’t go through with it now.
DOCTOR: We can, and you will. Leave us alone.
NICKY: (receding) Okay, okay.
MEL: Doctor, I’m sorry.
DOCTOR: Sorry? Sorry? Mel, you’ve just attacked our greatest ally.
MEL: Hold on. You don’t know the half of it. Our ally was talking on a communicator about her plan.
DOCTOR: Oh, Mel.
MEL: What?
DOCTOR: Haven't you worked it out? Didn’t you realise?
MEL: But I
DOCTOR: The clues were all there. Geri is a high-ranking Ambassador.
MEL: Yes.
DOCTOR: Why is she here, at the Intergalactic Song Contest?
MEL: Well, it’s still important, isn’t it?
DOCTOR: More important than any of us realise.
MEL: How?
DOCTOR: Mel, all this talk of the Peace Conference on Achilles Four.
MEL: Yes?
DOCTOR: There is no Peace Conference on Achilles Four. Whatever’s happening over there, it’s nothing but a side show. Dark Space Eight is what matters. This is the Peace Conference.

elements.text: [Part Four]
That doesn’t make sense. Nobody would trust this lot with keeping the peace.
I’m not sure they know, Mel. Listen. Angvia’s been knocked on the head.
I know that, but she’s
Mel! She’s been saying some very unusual things.
Well, that’s no surprise.
Mel. And the unusual things she’s been saying gave me the final clue to this whole sorry business.
Well?

If I’m right, the contestants from Earth, Angvia and Gholos are unwitting pawns in the peace process. The conference on Achilles Four is a mere diversion. An easy and obvious target for the terrorist groups. Under cover of the song contest, the delegations have been brought together in secret.
But they’re singers, entertainers. You’re not telling me that Nicky is a high ranking diplomat.

Well, no, but my guess is that he and the others have been implanted with subconscious telepathic imprints of the key delegates. When they arrived here at the station, within telepathic range of one another, those imprints would have been activated.
So if you’re right, the conference has been going on under our noses telepathically ever since.
Yes. Geri wasn’t here to arbitrate on a song contest.
She was here to ensure that the peace conference went ahead.
Eureka!
Ah. One thing’s still bothering me.
Really?
How you can be so incorrigibly smug. Why didn’t you tell me before instead of letting me run round like a loon accusing all and sundry?
Well, I didn’t know for sure until Angvia was coshed.
For sure, or at all?
All right. At all.
So not quite the Great Detective.
Well, I didn’t want to run around like a loon accusing all and sundry.
Hmm. So now we know the background, but are we any further forward in discovering who the murderer is?
Oh yes. The Great Detective’s figured that one out too. Bring Nicky to the ready room.
You must pull through, Arbiter. Dark Space Eight has seen enough death. Oh, I feel so. No. No. Where are those? Ah. Let’s see if this works.
Oh! You're trying to kill me!
Arbiter. Arbiter, you’re quite safe.
Poison. It’s poison.
Smelling salts, Miss Pakhar. An innovation of the Commander’s. You're in sickbay. You’ve taken a nasty knock to the head.
A nasty? Oh wait, I remember. That girl, the pilot, she tried to kill me. Oh!
Please, keep calm. We are investigating the attack. Pilot Mel is assisting the Commander with any

You mean she’s still loose? A maniac loose aboard Dark Space Eight? Another maniac loose aboard Dark Space Eight? No. No, no. She must be behind it. I insist she is locked in the brig, clapped in irons. That girl is a menace to us all! Oh!
Door opens during above speech.
Nonsense. Mel is a menace to nobody. Well, almost nobody. I’m glad to see that you’re feeling better, Arbiter.
I’m afraid she’s still very weak, Commander.
Yes, well, I’ll take things from here, Doctor Harcourt. Perhaps you could join the others in the guest lounge. I'll be in shortly.
But Commander, my duties
Are temporarily suspended. Please, Eleanor.
Very well, Commander.
Door closes. Angvia cries out.
Angvia, what?
I am on. I must go.
No, wait.
My makeup, my wardrobe, my wig! The shame!
Door opens and closes.
Oh well.
Look, Commander, what is all this about?
I think we have a great deal to talk about, Miss Pakhar. Are you sitting comfortably?
Cheers and applause.
And thank you, the Architects of Algol 7. Next up it’s time to welcome a lady that you all know, from a planet that you all know. It’s the Four Tops! No, I’m sorry, it isn’t. It’s Angvia!
Lots of drums.
42 I sing! I sing of Angvia! Most likely to win! Most beautiful men! Gor-raz A Det! Gor-raz A Det! Sweet Angvia! Oh Angvia. Gor-raz A Det! I singJd
[OC]: 4 I sing! I sing!.2
That hideous woman. If that is what passes for music on her homeworld, I
Turns off feed.
Oh no. There’s only another few acts and then it’s me.
Why has the Commander told us to wait here? I have duties in sickbay, and you two should be getting ready in the arena.
The Commander knows what he’s doing, believe me. If he says we stay here, we stay here.
For a mere pilot, you seem to know the Commander very well.
Cheers off.
Oh God.
Nicky, what is it?
It’s my tummy. It’s going loop the loop. Feels like something’s crawled in there and died.
Take deep breaths. Just think, the moment you step out onto the stage you'll feel fine. All your fears and doubts will melt away.
Oh God! Quick!
Quick, bag.
Nicky vomits.
Urgh.
Disgusting.
Door opens and closes.
In here? I cannot see why I
Commander’s orders, madam.
There, my performance, it is certain to win. That was a triumph! Well, didn’t anybody like it?
It was lovely. Well done. (claps)
Oh no. Now there’s only the Breebles, those cephalopod things, and the Drahvins to go, and then it’s Earth. Me!
For goodness’ sakes, stop being so selfish.
You'd feel selfish with a stomach like mine.
Door opens.
Ah. Here we all are.
Door closed and locked.
Commander, we’ve been waiting for you.
Good.
Arbiter, are you sure you’re well enough to be on your feet?
Quite sure, Doctor Harcourt.
Oh, and look, Geri, about earlier. I’m so sorry.
Later, Mel.
Coffee maker noise.
What is that thing, Arbiter?
A simple mechanical device that the Commander has just
Later, later, Arbiter. Well now, I suppose you’re all wondering why I’ve called you all here.
To unmask the murderer, surely.
Well, yes. Yes, yes. Well, right then. I’ve pressure-locked the doors, and there are guards posted outside. Nobody can leave this drawing room.
Ready room.
Ready room.
Commander, please be brief. Gholos is anxious to get back to the hall.
This is the denouement, Mister LooZly. I'll take as long as I like. Now, someone in this room is a murderer.
We know. Just tell us who it is, will you?
The Chipmunks finish their happy song. Cheers.

Ah, bless them. The Breebles there. Quite a favourite to win, I think. The excitement here is actually quite infectious. Even I’m starting to enjoy myself. Well, not that I wasn’t before, of course, but anyway, there’s a lot more excitement to come, and perhaps one or two surprises.
Achilles Four is a sham. This is the real Peace Conference. Somebody here intends to destroy it, and the murders were committed to throw suspicion onto one party.
Consternation.
This is a conference? What nonsense.
All true, your Majesty. A telepathic conference. The only way to ensure the negotiations could proceed uninterrupted.
Rubbish. And even if it were true, it obviously didn’t work.
Not quite. Because someone knew all along, eh, Doctor Harcourt?
John!
As a doctor, you’re not exactly up there with the greats, are you?
What do you mean?
I feel so helpless. I’ve run a series of tests. The results are negative. Inconclusive.
I’ve always tried my best.

And yet so many people have died. You said Cyrene died from natural causes. Wrong. You said Angvian physiognomy was different from human physiognomy. Wrong. You didn’t see that Professor Fassbinder had been poisoned, and it was staring you in the face. You couldn’t revive Angvia when all she had was a bump on the head.
John, I don’t know what to say.
No, you never do. The thing that puzzled me almost from the very beginning
Yes?
Mel, when we found the Cyrene, you accidentally called me Doctor. I don’t know why.
Er, yes, I was a bit confused, I suppose.
I looked up and answered you because, among my many qualifications, I am in fact a doctor.
I never knew that.
I looked up, but Eleanor didn’t, because she is not a doctor.
Sound of masticating to a fast beat, finishing with a bathtub draining. Polite applause.

Well, er, a very expressive and interesting er song there from the Cissalian Cephalopods. Perhaps not entirely this audience’s cup of tea, or glass of beer, rather. (cheers) I’m getting rather good at this.
But Doctor Harcourt, you must be a doctor.
I, I, no. No, I am not. The Commander is right.
Let’s hear the truth for once. You aren’t qualified in space medicine and a dozen other subjects.

No. But I wanted to be. I wanted to hurry down corridors in a spotless white gown, my nostrils flaring. I wanted to carry out tests. I wanted to cure people and carry out dangerous operations. And I did.
You pretended. No wonder so many people have died over the years with you in charge.

But some survived. I did some good. I stowed away here on a shuttle years ago, told everybody I was a doctor on attachment to Dark Space Eight, and they just believed me. I think I started to believe it myself. I felt so helpless.
I get it. You committed the murders because you were being blackmailed.
No! I had nothing to do with the murders.
Why should we believe you now?
Because she’s telling the truth.
How do you know that? The woman is a self-confessed liar.
But not murder. Never murder.
Come on, Commander. Give us the proof.
Proof? There is no proof. Because Eleanor is not the murderer.
What? Then for goodness’ sakes who is?
Ah.
Who is it?
Perhaps we should turn our attentions to you, Nicky Newman.
Cheers.

Well, the tension is really building here in the auditorium as we wait for the next part of tonight’s show to be played out. And I’m told that this next segment is a doozy. Let’s see what you think at home.
Yes, Nicky, you’ve been hovering in the background all along. The perfect innocent.
But it can’t be him.
Why not? Nobody has suspected him, even for a moment.
No, it’s not me.
What?
I’ve never killed anyone. Oh no, I’m going to end up in the middle of a miscarriage of justice. Oh God, I’m going to be sick again.
You're not saying he killed three people just so he wouldn't have to sing? That’s ludicrous.
Indeed. Utterly ludicrous.
But
But what?
Aren’t you going to say but, and then tell us why he did it?
No. Because he is what he appears. Innocent.
Then why bring him here?
Because I wanted to distract him from the contest and make him realise how trivial his worries are. I hope I’ve taught you a lesson, young man.
You mean, you don’t think it’s me?
Of course it isn’t you. You’re nothing to do with it.
Oh, thank God.
So, in a moment you can go and sing and stop making such a blithering fuss. Just learn your lines and try not to bump into the orchestra.
Right. Now, please, who is it?
Who do you think? The shuttle was destroyed by an Angvian scatter-bomb. Cyrene was killed with Angvian poison. Professor Fassbinder was killed by Angvian neural bind.
No. No!
Yes. And she tried to corrupt you, Commander.
Hmm. Though admittedly we were warned about that.
But, what, you mean the note? I thought that didn’t make sense.
Oh, but it did. Beware the pits of Angvia. Geri?
Yes, it was I who tried to warn the Commander. I have heard of the Angvian love rituals.
No!
Yes. I have special access to certain documents, and among them was one pertaining to the Angvian pheromone glands.
We Angvians are renowned
For being almost irresistible to most males because of the chemicals you excrete from the glands in your pits.
I get it. In her arm pits. That’s why you took a funny turn.
At last, Commander. This is what Gholos has been trying to tell you all along. Angvia is a murderess and a threat to us all.
Yes.
No, Commander! My little man, no.
Yes, Gholos has been trying to tell us who the murderer is all along.
Exactly.
We should have listened.
Arrest her.
So it was Angvia?
Oh no, Mel. Whatever made you think that?
What?
Geri, switch on the translator.
The translator has been programmed with Logan’s voice.
Ah yes, it is Loozly. Loozly is the murderer.
Cheers.

And now we can take a peek into the contestant’s green room where the atmosphere is electronic. Electric. There we have the Zilphens. Quite a wait for them tonight. And over there are the Breebles, celebrating their rapturous reception by oh. Oh dear. Naughty Breebles. Anyway, moving swiftly on.
Uh, uh, uh, it’s all over for you now, LoozZzly.
This is nonsense. That is not the voice of Gholos. It’s that, that, that commentator.

That is purely perceptual. This unit was being worked on by Mister Logan before he met his death. The Doctor has completed his work. The voice synthesiser was programmed from Logan’s own voice, it would seem.

Now, Mister Loozly, the fierce Gholosian nationalist. Of course you’d be bitterly opposed to the peace process. From your friends in Earth security you learned about the fake peace conference, and inveigled your way here as Gholos’s translator.
This is lies, all lies.
I imagine you planned to destroy the conference, the whole station, make your escape, and throw all the blame onto the Angvian retrospectively.
By framing her.

Yes. He tried to destroy our shuttle with what looked like an Angvian scatter-bomb. You killed Cyrene and Ivor with Angvian weapons, then you coshed Angvia to make the others think she was double- bluffing.
You have a very active imagination, Commander.
Why, thank you. It’s always been one of my ambitions to write the Great Intergalactic Novel.
Back to the point.

Oh yes. But real life has a habit of being stranger than fiction. It must have been very frustrating for you, Loozly. Nobody rose to your bait, did they? With a chief scientist and medical officer who couldn’t tell a scatter-bomb or Angvian poison from their elbows, your plan didn’t work as well as it might have.
Thank goodness you’re a genuine commander, Commander.
Quite. But even I
Oh, please.
Even I only realised for sure when I noticed the change in Gholos’s behaviour, when he came to the ready room earlier, followed by Loozly. The only time anyone had seen him without you.
Except me, when it attacked me. He called it off.
I was not attacking you, young human. I was just trying to tell you what I’d just discovered, that Loozly had killed Cyrene.
But you couldn’t because he was translating for you.

Exactly. And then he started to subdue me with his so-called monitor device. He threatened to cut me off from the gestalt completely. And ever since then, he has misreported everything I was trying to say.
Why isn’t his control box working now?
Geri?
Because I built a wide-range dampening function into the translator unit. I suspected he must have some sort of hold over you.
Then I must thank you, Arbiter.
So, you can take your finger off that button, Loozly.
But why would Loozly kill Logan the commentator?
Because he was working on this translator device. He was talking about it when Loozly was in the rest sphere.
Of course! He would have blown his plan clean out of the water.

Exactly. So, Loozly had to put him out of the way. Bit of a rush job that one, though. No time to concoct an Angvian attack, so a knife in the back and problem solved. Strange that the Professor seemed to have cottoned on. Obviously he wasn’t quite the wreck we all took him for. Was that why you bumped him off, Mister Loozly?
Pah.
But wait. The Gholos creature turned red. The Red Sting of Gholos. He must have been working with this human.
(laughs) There’s no such thing as the Red Sting.
We all took red to mean Gholos was angry, dangerous. In fact, it was a warning light.
I was trying to communicate with you, the only way I could.
Well, Mister Loozly? Anything to say?

What’s the point of pretending? Yes, I did it. I did it all. And I’d do it all again. All for the love of Gholos! The gestalt is a wonderful thing. Serene, implacable, timeless. It must never be sullied by contact with the Angvian filth. Gholos is pure. Pure, I say! This, this splinter of Gholos has already been tainted by contact with, with you fleshy fools.
But you’re as much a fleshy fool as any of us.
Oh, I wish I wasn’t.
Guard Captain.
Yes, sir.
Take this man away, poor misguided fool that he is.
Oh, Commander, you’re an intelligent man. Don’t you understand?

Understand, Mister Loozly? I'll tell you what I understand. This is a big universe. Centuries of hate, the clash of cultures, death on all sides, nothing but pride and death. It’s time to drop it. We’ve got to live together. Our one short silly meaningless lives are important. Join the universe, Mister Loozly. Leave hate behind.
Yes. Yes, you're right. Of course you're right. Perhaps I have been misguided. I never wanted to kill. It was just that
Thud, thump, Angvia cries out.
Right. One move from any of you and Angvia will be the first to die.
Loozly, no!
Let her go. This isn’t going to help you.
No? Then perhaps this will.
Look, mate, you heard what the Arbiter said. Your little control gizmo won’t work any more. Now just give up.
Perhaps the hairy pest managed to block my subjugation beam, but I wouldn’t be willing to bet that she’s blocked the signal from this switch.
Er, what does that do?
I press this, the station is destroyed immediately. Simple as that.
But that’s crazy. You'd die too.
Worth it, to save the gestalt.
He is bluffing. You must argh.

That’s enough from you. Commander, you will prepare a shuttle for me. Angvia will accompany me as my insurance. I can assure you she will come to no harm. (laughs) Well, perhaps assure might be overstating it.
It seems I underestimated you, Mister Loozly. You’re not only misguided, you’re also utterly insane.
Sticks and stones, Commander. Now, do as I say or argh!
Fizzing, thud.
Let the Blue Sting of Gholos do its work. I am avenged.
Loozly lets out a long death rattle.
Your Majesty, are you all right?
Oh, it, it saved my life.
The human Loozly is dead. So perish all who dare to threaten the gestalt.
I, I thank you, Gholos.
And I thank you, Commander, for freeing me.
It was nothing. Any passing genius would have done the same. But if you want to do me a favour, speak with Angvia. I feel sure that your two races can find some common ground. Agreed?
I owe you a debt. If that is how you wish to be repaid.
And we of Angvia owe Gholos a debt. The meeting will be arranged.
Wonderful. Well, I think that just about
Ah, hold on, genius. How did Loozly intend to destroy the station?
Oh yes. Oh, well remembered, Mel, yes. I’m sure we'll find something large and loud, probably one of those nasty bomb things, hidden amongst his things if we search his room.
I suggest we return to our duties.
Mister White to arena.
Oh no. I’ve got to go on, then.
Sounds like it.
Haven't you learned your lesson, young man?
Yeah, yeah. I’m fine now. You really made me see that there’s nothing to be afraid of. I mean, what is it? All I have to do is stand up and sing in front of billions of people. It’s not like oh.
Come, child. I will lead you to the stage.
I mean, it’s all been a bit of a shock, all these revelations. And Mister Loozly, I thought he was nice. He was really kind to me.
Door opens.
Make sure he goes on.
I will.
See you later, Mel. Oh, do I have to?
Door closes.
I must also return to my duties. Gholos, will you join me?
Oh, I mean, yes, Arbiter. Catch you later, everyone.
Door opens and closes.
Doctor?
Yes?
Eleanor.
Oh, yes. Well, what have you got to say for yourself, Miss Harcourt?
John, I’m, I’m so sorry. I just wanted to live my dream.
Ah. I suppose we ought to just let you slip quietly away.
Doctor! This woman’s caused untold deaths through her fantasising. You can’t just let her slip away.
No. No, I suppose I can’t. Oh, that’s for the jury to decide. Take her away, Captain.
Yes, sir.
Oh, John. John. (crying)
Door opens and closes.
That’s more like it.
Hmm. I’m not so sure I like all this commanding. Too many difficult decisions. Well, Mel, let’s find the Tardis, shall we, so I can get back to some good old-fashioned Doctoring again.
Theme tune starts.
Doctor.
Theme tune scrapes to a halt.
Yes?
It’s too easy.
What?
The way everything’s been wrapped up.
Well, it has. Hasn't it?
Cheers.

And that was the Drahvin entry. Marga 29 there with Cloned Love. Now, who’s next? Oh yes, I see, the old home planet. Earth has given us so many great songs over the centuries. Greensleeves, Mull of Kintyre, and of course Right On Time. And now we have Nicky Newman!
Cheers.

Yes, as I was saying, here’s Nicky! Yes, here he is. Oh. Apparently someone’s just handed me a piece of paper to say there’s been a slight delay. So we are all to join in with the Earth National Anthem.
Organ plays.
J At first I was afraid J
Door opens and closes.
(Michael Caine) Commander Ballard. We’ve searched Mister Loozly’s quarters. There is no bomb.
See? It’s like I said. Too easy.
He must have planted the bomb somewhere else.
Impossible, sir. We've carried out a full security scan, double-checked the entire station. There is no bomb.
So Loozly was bluffing? No. That just doesn’t add up.
Quite right. Well?
Well what?
Any ideas?
Come on, Doctor, I’m relying on you to be two steps ahead as per.
Door opens.
Ah, Commander, Melanie.
Door closes.
I have just delivered Nicky to the concert hall. He protested, but we women of Angvia accept no quibbles from our menfolk.
Shush, Angvia. I’m just trying to work something out. Now, this station is bristling with security devices. Now how could he get a bomb on board?
Well, it must have been camouflaged.
Everything brought aboard the station is scanned.
The boy’s jumping like an Angvian leaping bean.
How do you smuggle an explosive powerful enough to rip apart twenty million tons of super- bonded herculanium?
Well, I would use an Angvian personal destructor.
It must be enormous.
Not necessarily. It could be tiny and still enormously destructive.
An Angvian personal destructor would do it. One of our greatest weapons.
Loozly came in on the relay shuttle flight with Nicky. Perhaps he saw something?
Good thinking. We'll question him after his song.
An Angvia personal destructor would be the perfect weapon, but Gholos lag centuries behind our technology. Loozly could not have obtained such a device.
